content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								Fraud and LiesOK I know that the mods are keeping a tight leash on the forums here and they are shutting down everything that is pointing out the truth so I am going lash out and hope that a few people see this before it gets locked or myself banned like many others have before. There are a lot of Early Access games on steam. Most of them have a capable and dedicated development team behind them. We all know this, we are all playing their games. We know what to expect from Alphas, Betas, Early Access etc etc. And this isn't it. This game has changed very very little for more than a year now. And they are still taking peoples money for it.The people that originally backed this game are for the most part gone - they check in every few months hoping that something has changed but it hasn't. At this stage the only people that are happy with this game are those that have recently bought it in the last couple of months and don't know that a patch isn't 'just around the corner', and those that are friends with the devs who jump on every negative review and defend it with the usual "Alpha", "Early Access", or "refactoring" excuses.We aren't stupid. We have played plenty of Early Access games before. They all need to be refactored a couple of times during their development as the scope of the interest in the game increases. All the early access games we are playing are doing the same. Castle Story is NOT unique in this.The devs just use refactoring as an excuse for having not produced anything notable for more than a year. This is rubbish. They have accumulated near enough to a million dollars to work on this project and all they do is stall.I know there are a lot of others out there that are just as fed up with this rubbish, and I hope it serves as a lesson to everyone to be very careful as to what they back with Early Access games. There a plenty of good ones out the with dedicated developers, but there are also a few rotten eggs.I'd like to hear from everyone that has been through the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥e and all those that were banned for speaking out about this, but I know they probably have given up on this game plus anyway it won't be long before this thread is locked down and removed anyway. I feel sorry for everyone that wasted their money - I had hoped for something special too.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								Update 20NOV16:Just keeping this review fresh, it now has more content and updates than this game.  Still no meaningful changes to the game, still barely playable, still missing features, still full of bugs.  Feels like it has actually regressed, the early alpha from 4+ years ago felt more finished than this game does now.  Really think about that.  What were you doing in your life 4 years ago?  How much has changed for you since then, professionally, personally?  Have you finished any life goals, at all?  The devs for this game haven't!Winter sale season is coming up soon, don't be fooled by their 'updates' it's all a gimick to look busy and net sales.Update 10FEB16:Just wanted to update again to keep this review current with development.  Yup, nothing has changed since last time.  Update done.Ok, there are many patch notes, none of them actual content, all of them coincide with the winter sales event.  Dev's are still trying to grab cash while clumsily and incompetantly releasing trivial updates in time for a sale.  Game has actually regressed, which I didn't think was possible.  UI continues to get worse with every iteration, less intuitive, more complex, less functional, and bugs with AI grow ever more intrusive.  Avoid this "game*" at all costs.* A game is technically any sort of interactive entertainment where choices by a player lead to and change a possible outcome.  None of that happens here, there is no outcome other than you wasting time and money in anticipation of a crash or game breaking bug.Update 30AUG15:Well, summer is over.  Another round of shotgun blast Sauropod updates has passed.  Nothing of actual significance has been added to the game yet again.  Just making this update to point out that every sale season (WInter/Summer) Sauropod blasts out a ton of updates right before the sale, so potential new customers will walk in, say "Wow, those guys really turned it around and get making progress!".  When the reality is, they're using the update ticker as a daily news feed for stuff they've thought about, and haven't actually done.  They will also roll a minor trivial change in something out as 3 or 4 updates.  Don't be fooled, there has not been an update. It's a shameful and deceptive practice and really shows the developers for the dishonest incompetents they are.  If there was any doubt in your mind about whether to label them as "Just bad developers" or "Actual thieves", this is all you need to know to decide.Update 21DEC14:I figured I would update the review considering how much activity the dev's have had lately.  But it seems it was all just lip service.  Over the last few weeks they've been shotgunning loads of update announcements, but the reality of the situation is those were all just announcements for one single update.  That update itself was absolutely trivial, and seems to have added nothing of substance to the game.  The devs constantly give the excuse of "reworking" and "redeveloping" engine components of the game, but these changes never seem to result in any sort of actual impact to the game.  For all their bluster, a disapointingly little amount has changed, and all assumptions about them have been confirmed.  This is just shameless PR propaganda.The sad fact is, if you're the lunk head that invented a square wheel, taking a year off to invent an octagonal wheel leaves you as still a lunk head.  I don't think I'll be revisiting this game until it's final release, whenever that may be.Final thoughts for now:  Stay away.  With luck they'll go bankrupt and sell all IP to a competant developer.*Original*Overall, I do enjoy this game, and probably had more anticipation for this than any other early access I've followed.  So why do I not recommend this?  Bullets:Cons:- No updates!  Years have passed and the game is still in a less functional state than their fictional tech demo.- Current state is playable, but quickly reveals how broken it is.  Terrible AI, limited functoinality of game mechanics, limited... game.- Devs hate the community.  Well probably not hate, but this is the crux of it.  There appears to be absolutely no effort being made to update the game in an actual and meaningful way.  When pressed for answers from the community as to when we can expect something new, the same canned response of 'we don't give deadlines' is the answer.  That's fine after a few months, but not after a few years.  The first major red light for me when nearly a years worth of dev updates were about how they spent a month and a half working on a new sound effect for an object that isn't even in the game, or here's a new soundtrack I've been listening to, or "Hey, we're going on vacation!".  While glaring issues remain untouched and unaddressed.  PR people are hired to quell criticism and silence community dissent.-Devs are in over their heads.  A lot of people will call them theives, or scammers, I don't see it as that.  They are still around.  They are still 'working'.  But it really seems like they've all retreated to their little comfort zones, and feverishly work on silly little things like a sound effect to the exclusion of actual game problems.  Why would they do this?  Well, it seems pretty clear that they have realized they cannot handle those bigger problems, and just seem to be hoping they'll fix themselves tomorrow.  Their production efforts are terribly misguided, and no one seems able to get the train back on the tracks.  This is the main reason I think the community has given up on them.  There are gracious ways out of this connundrum for them, but they seem completely unwilling to compromise, admit their shortcomings, and work with the community.  For that they have failed utterly at making a game.  A community college degree does not a game dev make.Pros:- Build a big castle block by block, watch a nearly good physics engine crush it.- If you give them enough money to keep the lights on, you get a t-shirt or something, someday.

Not the mention the game was in prototype for OVER A YEAR. that's bad, Don't even bother with the game. The islands are boring and repetitive, it should be randomly generated, not the same old crappy map. It's simply boring, broken, and just flat out annoying.EDIT:Congratz, Sauropod Studio, It's been 2 years since you released the game to the public and It's still in Early Access. Really, I accomodate you and your hard work for this terribly optimized, bugged game. It seems improvement has obviously been made. (Obvious Sarcasm)

content:
Posted: September 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								I foolishly paid money for this game when it first came out on steam, in the two years since then they have done nothing of note to the actual game. They've been to PAX east, they've ordered in Castle Story T-shirts and Castle Story plushies, they've hired bearded men to make videos of people looking busy, they've deleted my posts on their youtube videos and they've deleted my posts on the community hub and banned me from posting there again, they've got new gaming rigs, they've painted the walls of their office with a cool Castle Story mural, they've been out in the woods making noises, they've played Magicite, once again what they HAVEN'T done is anything of note to the game itself. The game in its current state is "OK" for a buggy unfinished alpha, not much content to speak of, certainly not worth £14.99. These developers sold everyone a pack of lies and hired people to censor out anyone that calls them out on their unethical, thieving and unprofessional behaviour. I can think of many games that have far more content and regular updates and better developers (in terms of listening to and communicating with the community) that cost far less. An example of their lying can be found in the trailer, you are led to believe that there are two types of enemies, it shows a larger corruptron throwing rocks at the castle. This is an outright lie, there is no such thing in the game. The only other game I can think of recently with this kind of unethical misrepresentation of the product is War Z with its crawling zombies in the trailer.The future for Castle Story is bleak, most people who were going to buy it have already bought it long ago when it first came to steam, since then the developers have completely failed to deliver. Any criticism of their unprofessional behaviour by the community is ignored or censored. They have all the money they're going to get so there is simply no more reason to work on the game any further. Instead they are hiring more and more staff to sell it to people on the internet and make promises that will never be kept to create the illusion that they are still working on the game.I expect that in time they will change the name of the game as War Z did to squeeze out those last few sales before it is consigned to the dustbin of history as yet another kickstarter project that made the devs very rich but utterly failed to deliver on its promises.Do not give these unethical, thieving and unprofessional developers any of your money, to do so would encourage others to follow their lead.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								DO NOT BUY! Sauropod studios are run by a very small group of inexperienced, unapologetic jerks. If you bought in to this game through kickstarter or early access, they will treat you like crap on the forums.The only thing Castle Story had going for it was the amazing work the Community Manager: Box, was doing. Box would try to give information to you straight, without breaking any of the company rules, which was very difficult to do. Box would always try to break information down to the community and calm people down who were angry about any of the situations. In the end, the company would give Box misleading information and then blame him for giving out any information to the community.One of the primary developers for Castle Story is a dev named Thierry. Thierry has a tendency to berate the community for asking questions. On multiple occasions I've read post by him calling out individuals and virtually yelling at them, or the community in general and blaming them for being impatient. The game has been in development for years now, and there has literally been no visual improvement in over a year.Originally there were weekly updates on what was going on, with an occasional skipping of a week or two. Now there are monthly updates on what is going on. I take that back. There are monthly video blogs about things nobody cares about. These "monthly" video blogs have only made it up to the 3rd blog before they seem to have stopped posting them. It has been six weeks since the last video blog, which is probably a good thing, because they're useless information anyway.TL;DR, STAY AWAY FROM THIS GAME. The devs will treat you like crap, and blame the community for asking too many questions, the game has been stagnant for over a year. The forums have started seeing posts deleted, and users are getting banned for giving out useful information, and asking real questions respectfully.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
Early Access Review
								I know what you're thinking. Surely, right now the game is on sale and you're looking at the reviews to see if the game is worth $12.99-$14.99 because what kind of customer would you be if you didn't?You see some good reviews--"Recommended! Yes! What a great game! Has some work to do, but worth it!" and so you continue to look, just in case. Then you'll see bad reviews--"Do not recommend! No! Horrible game! Has a ton of work to do, and not worth it!" You see a couple of these, but you decide you want to make your own decision on the matter.You'll look back at the screen shots, review some videos, and see that the game is hella cute, has a good looking play style, and an interesting concept.You'll ignore the bad reviews and buy the game anyways.You install.The game is beautiful, so it doesn't disappoint on that front.The game is fairly easy to play, so ~30 minutes in, you'll have the controls down for the most part and basic strategies for castle building.After ~1h, you'll get bored of your first castle and start anew, with a different strategy in mind.You'll be fairly successful with your second castle, and you'll have a lot of the mechanics behind the game worked out, making this new castle easier.Now this is where I don't know what you'll do. I, personally, got bored of the second castle. I realized the only thing I can do is expand on my castle with what little land I had (digging/terraforming isn't as easy as it should be, so I wouldn't consider that a feature.) On top of that, building is pretty slow, so that takes a while (gets pretty boring to me pretty fast.) On top of THAT, the AI is still pretty wonky, so the Bricktrons aren't as efficient as they could be.This game has a ton of potential, don't get me wrong. When crafting, new game modes, and just more stuff is added, I'll revisit it. But for now, I wouldn't say this game isn't even worth $10 as it is. Save your money, spend it on a more complete game.

Early Access Review
								Edit: 01/11/2015A year after my last update on the game, with the release of 0.5, I tried this once again. Some new blocks added; beams, supports, stone pillar, curved blocks.UI - radial menu- is counter intuitive; too slow and complicated. Designed to be used with a gamepad, not keyboard+mouse.AI is still braindead; pathfinding is as broken as it can be. You still can't build a structure even as small as this without constantly micro maniging.


pathfinding bonked 
A Screenshot of Castle Story
By: Kleidophoros




Notice that he is standing right on top the blueprint he should be building. So he can reach it with the block but too dumb to do it.Started new map, didn't build anything, didn't create any tasks, didn't give any orders, just selected all 5 bricktons and moved them in front of the pre-built castle; 3 of them made it, 2 got stuck on the way. Heh, so much for improved pathfinding.


Castle Story 
A Screenshot of Castle Story
By: Kleidophoros




Big Island doesn't even load for me; stuck at "Loading %0".Multiplayer is still as broken as it can be.Some Halloween stuff again; lanterns and stuff.And to think they will release this in a few months. I really can't believe Sauropod.Still no real update, no real content, still the same old broken game.Stay away!------------------Edit: 29/10/2014So after 2 years, a new patch downloaded just now; it contains 2 new hats, one for archer and one for knight. And the floating soul thingies are now ghosts. No other visible additions so far. Will see if there will be patch notes or not.Edit: No patch notes; just some Halloween themed visual changes. Unbelievable.After 2 years we had a refactoring, a few bug fixes and a pause button. Map editor is gone.Multiplayer is as broken as it can be.Still no new content.----------Original review:I am a Kickstarter backer so I have been following the development of the game for about 1,5 years. This ride started great, these guys had an awasome concept, gameplay movies to show and so I backed their project. They were supposed to deliver the beta in October 2012; now we are in Early Access and still in early prototype. But the real problem is the lack of information about the development process; dev. dairies are void of any solid info; they are just about bugfixes and trivial stuff; t-shirts, save/load game functions, technical mumbo jumbo.. We don't know where this game is going; no real direction or roadmap presented by devs. There is talk of a roadmap though; for many, many months if I remember correctly. I suspect they have not known what to do with their game since the beginning. I just can't explain the lack of any solid info about the game/roadmap/direction in any other way.Since the first prototype of the game, over a year ago, devs have added a really, really broken survival mode to the game, a multiplayer mode which doesn't work, a few bugfixes here and there; nothing else. Game has a lot of potential, a great concept but the execution is just plain bad; UI is horrible, there are no real updates, no content added in over a year since first release. I do not recommend the game at this point. At this rate devs working on the game; come back in a year or two and maybe, maybe you might be looking at a good game. Otherwise just stay away for now.About the game itself:It's sandbox building game. You have minions doing various tasks like mining, cutting down trees and providing you with building materials on the map you choose; well you have just one map at the moment so no choosing. You issue orders to your minions to gather materials and then you go ahead and lay down blueprints for your minions and they build them. In Survival mode; you have baddies on top of normal sandbox mode. But they have no AI so they just rush at you. Get an archer or two at a high place and you win. Baddies won't be able to climb more than 2 blocks high and it takes too much time to destroy the blocks; your archers will kill everyone while baddies are hacking away at the blocks.Problems;UI is horrible. unimaginative and clunky.Camera controls are plain bad.There are still problems with laying down blueprints for constructions. Pathfinding is broken, AI is broken; blueprints for big buildings are very problematic; your minions just can't build them due to pathfinding errors. Especially big blueprints will give you a headache; you will have to zoom in, out, rotate the camera this way and that just to be able to lay down a blueprint. Misclick? Tough luck; some blueprints blocks just don't wanna be removed so you will end up dropping that building and start another blueprint.Many times you will have to start a map over and over again to get minions to spawn at all; you will just start with no minions.There is a catapult in the game with which you can hurl barrels filled with stones or explosive stones to baddies. Very clunky to use; you will end up not using it at all. You don't want to use explosive barrels too; you will just destroy your buildings with it.No content added as of now. You just build aimlessly in the map. There aren't enough building blocks. There aren't enough info about the game mechanics; how do you build that bridge for example? You will have to find some YouTube video by a fellow player to show you that.Why can't you just put that block over there? Because you can't. And no one tells you why not.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								I bought this game about 18 months ago.It was a great concept, and a really fun game to play with knowing that much more content was promised and on the way.I was dissapointed to find out shortly after obtaining the game that they were essentially suspending any new features pending a 'refactoring' in the Unity game engine.  The good news was that once this was done, they were to start pumping out feature and content updates much more quickly, since they were including an improved asset pipeline.That took much more time than their community liason had let on.  The community (other investors in the game) were getting pretty restless.  Finally that refactoring was completed.  A patch was released!  Unfortunately, it had little to no impact on the gameplay.  There were some minor stability improvements but no real new features or content.  We were okay with that because of the promise of much more coming more quickly...  We were then informed that we were being too impatient, and that no new features or content could be done until they finished working on their internal tools (factories).We were then informed that there would continue to be a suspension of any new features or content while they rewrite the AI engine and the Pathfinding.   No new content could be provided since "Why would we give you new content if the AI cant figure out what to do with that content"...   Of course most users abandoned hope that this would ever be completed.   It had been month after month after month of broken promises.   They eventually ended their relationship with the community liason, citing that he never really spoke for the company, and his promises were unfounded.Now, FINALLY.. version 0.3 has been released!!  (coincidentally timed with a Steam promotion) With the new AI, the new Pathfinding, new lighting effects, a bigger island to work with.Unfortunately, there is still no new content, no new features.   Leading up to a sale on Steam, they put together a nice little video of the new features ..   New AI (Which is worse than the original).. New Lighting (Which is of zero impact on the gameplay).. a bigger island (which is probably among the bottom 2% of necessary changes)..They then 'cleaned' out the user forums of most negative feedback..   Unfortunately even after these years of waiting, the new 'version' was even more buggy and had less (YES LESS) features than the original.  The great new AI that was promised could only be 'tested' in a seperate environment, where the feature set was limited, and even that was far worse than the original, very buggy, AI.They started releasing (Very minor) bug fixes almost daily, appeasing many, even though they really only addressed things like difficulty in loading the game, or glitchy graphic artifacts, etc ..  These fixes and patches (0.3.1,  0.3.2,  0.3.3,  0.3.4)  started giving some of us the impression that this past couple of years of unfulfilled and broken promises was at an end and the momentum would finally change.   Unfortunately, although those changes were welcome if only to see that there was actually some level of activity going on..   They were short lived.  4 patches in 5 days.  Then nothing.. again.   This game has great potential as a concept.  But if you are considering it.. You would be very well advised to wait until you can read the reviews of the finished game.

Posted: April 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								The game is currently not worth buying but the devs are trying to fix all the problems. Keep an eye on this game but don't buy it yet. Edit:Updates are slow and bare minimum. This game is probably never going to be playable. Even trying to leave the game on overnight to gather resources feels like a waste of electricity.Edit 2:As of December 7th 2015 this game is now playable. The AI is improved enough that Castles can be completed; however not the most efficient pathing. Survival was fun but lagged past playable when I reached the 6th wave on easy. My computer can run Fallout 4 (on High) so If yours can't then dont buy this. The game is at a stage where I feel it should have started for early access. I wouldn't recomend anyone looking for a serious strategy game to buy this but, if you want to support a very new development team who seems to be trying to complete this game despite multiple set backs Buy it. I think the average person could get 2 hours of fun. While I have played far more most of those hours I wish I could get back. Hopefully in the near Future I can finally, after years, switch to my review to a thumbs Up.

number of helpful: 134 of 164 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								THIS REVIEW IS IN PURGATORY: I'm working on writing a new one. On October 27, 2015 Sauropod Studios released Castle Story 0.5, which seems to be FULL OF CONTENT AND FEATURES. Time will tell if they will start releasing updates on a reasonable schedule, and it remains to be seen if the game will be finished. But read the review with an open mind; things are looking better than when I wrote it.Original review:This game cost me $20 USD or so, and gave me 113 hours of enjoyment. That's over five hours of play per dollar -- certainly more than I've gotten out of some AAA titles that cost me three times that much. It was a fun little game.So why the thumbs down? Well, because despite being a somewhat *fun* game, it's not a *complete* game. And at this point it is not clear to me that the game will EVER be complete.The devs posted this disclaimer long ago: http://www.sauropodstudio.com/steam-early-access-disclaimer/ stating the features that work and those that are planned. The disclaimer is pretty accurate, it doesn't lie about what's working and what's not. The problem is that the "what's working" list has not grown by a single item since I bought the game -- litterally the ONLY feature of any note that has been added was a pause function -- which would have been greatly appreciated if I hadn't worn out the gameplay many months ago -- but they haven't made any visible progress towards that complete feature set they said they were planning.Some of this is understandable. It's a young studio, this is their first game and the developers are less experienced than those on a lot of other games. They made some early mistakes and had to refactor the code base, which took a long time. Normally, refactoring (while frustrating for end users because it consumes time with no new features) is useful because it reduces future bugs and makes implementing new features later much easier. But these things only matter if you RELEASE UPDATES after the refactoring.As I said, this is the studio's first game, and as you can see it's not going super well. It's entirely possible that they are out of money and about to go bankrupt for all I know. So it's impossible to say when or even if this game will get another update, or if a hypothetical update would even contain any significant improvements.So while it really boils down to the typical early access mantra of "Only pay for it if you are happy with the CURRENT state of the game", and while the current state of the game WAS worth the money I paid for it, I can't really recommend this game because I know that most people are less easy to please than I am, and want a finished product. This game may never be that.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								Buy Castle Story? No, but why not? A 2 year summaryI'm watching the development since almost two years and played over 160 hours. Only survival mode because there are no other challanges. Sandbox mode didn't really interested me after all, you know minecraft?Following Bugs and missing game options bother me since the first time i played. There has been changes and improvments but nothing got really fixed to a point im happy with. I guess a lot of other people feel the same after reading reddit and other sources, pointing out there's no progress would be wrong, but the prioritisation is amiss. I understand the process of prototyping, alphas and early access. But there shut be a noticable progress in all directions after two years of development.- building menu - Castle Story uses some kind of nice circular menu, it has a nice appeal in the first place. But really nerves after using it, because its inconvenient. You need to do the following steps to choose one of your main building materials; 1x1 stone bricks: hold down the right mousebutton, the main menu appears, move the mouse to submenu button, release the right mouse button, the main menu disapperas. Press the right mouse button again, the submenu apperas, move to the 1x1 stone, release right the mouse button, now you can place your bricks. You know what!? Let me use the left mouse button to select the submenu and the 1x1 brick, this would make the following steps redundant and the selection would be; hold right mouse button, left click submenu, left click desired option, DONE!?- blue Crystals - the Ore you need to gather for spawning new npcs is now stuck on stockpiles by default (version 0.3.3). This would be one of the very few added game mechanics in two years that made me happy, if turned off by default OMG. Now you have to manually order your broken Worker AI to carry the blue crystals to the main crystal or deaktivate the option on every stockpile you build... really?- demolishing - you can't demolish stockpiles, lamps, barrels,... If it does work and i didn't realise how, why doesn't it work the same way it does with stones and wood. By the way, if it works with stones and wood, does it take why more than 2 years to implement this feature?- zooming - nice to be able to zoom with the mousewheel, but only to a certain and low point. If users complain about that, they are told to use the old method, the caps key and mousewheel, now the can zoom infinite. What every sence restricting the "mousewheel only zoom" and having two ways to zoom after all may have. Only one way to zoom, problem fixed.- Workers - still get stuck in many different tasks. I know theres a new AI and it's not implemented in survival mode yet. Currently (version 0.3.3) the AI is a killjoy.- Swordsmen - useless as long as not standing in front of a gate. Because Enemys are past over before the realize there existence. Currently (version 0.3.3) the AI is a killjoy.- Archers - commit suicide by shoting there bows and killed other player npcs, this didn't happen anymore since version 0.3.0 and i played to wave 25. Thats a plus!i'm ♥♥♥♥ed, somebody else complete the list... Don't buy the game until it's released! Die Entwickler bewegen sich seit zwei Jahren im Kreis, mit einer Effizienz, die sich schön in ihrem Menü wiederspiegelt.

number of helpful: 100 of 119 people (84%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								It's a great concept, really! But the developers seem to be incapable of getting the game running properly. Been following its development for years now, and while I'm aware I purchased an Early Access game,  it's at the point now where I don't see this game ever being finished.  It has the same bugs and lack of content it did a year ago, the units don't respond well (or sometimes not at all) to commands, there's still no solid multiplayer, and the game still lags tremendously after a certain amount of waves.. This game isn't going anywhere, sadly. Unplayable.I strongly urge you not to buy this game.Second review, 19-02-2015:I stand by my statement that the game has not yet reached the point of "money's worth." However, it seems I was wrong about this game never going to be finished.The latest patch still leaves a lot to be desired, but they did fix the general unit control. Units still "dumb down" every now and then, but at least this time around you get to give them new orders once you've moved them manually. Where I couldn't even get past wave 15 in the past, I am surprised to say the game managed to get me to wave 35 without any framedrop. I paused the game to have a little drinky and edit my review, games tend to take a while. It's actually quite fun without lagspikes. I've heard friends mention they've made it up to wave 50-or-so, and then it started lagging.I still don't recommend this game as it is now, because multiplayer is still barely functional. If you want to play with a friend, get ready to search forums for a while, 'cause it doesn't come with complete instructions. But it is starting to look like we might see this game in a finished state after all.What I would like to see before I start recommending this game:- Playable framerate up to at least wave 100.- An easier way of getting rid of rubble. Either by despawning it, or having the bricktrons clean up quicker, I've noticed the game now starts lagging due to the amount of rock chips lying around.- An enjoyable multiplayer mode. Let's face it, this game can be summed up as tower defense meets lego. Don't get me wrong, it's fun! But we could use a co-op mode against the AI instead of a vague deathmatch where nobody is quite sure what to do and when to do it.- Catapults to be useful for either blowing up terrain or killing the rockmen.

								(Patch 0.6) Since the first beta, i try every new patch, and i've always been disapointed by the way everything was slow and unsteady. I think that this patch is a turning point. The Minitrons are flying everywhere, most of the action is fluid, the pathfinding is fast and the AI look like it understand what is going on (they don't exaggerate when they say the pathfinding is 100X faster or more). Still, beware, this game is far from finish, but i have a good feeling about the upcoming releases. Bravo à toute l'équipe de Sauropod!

content:
Posted: August 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								Castle Story is a castle building strategy game with delightful cartoonish graphics and a fun premise.You order around a group of little yellow warriors, gathering resources and supplies to build a castle, to protect a large crystal that serves as a spawner for your units. All of this on the fairly simple-though-attractive backdrop of some flying islands in the sky.Sadly, that's about where the charm of the game ends and the problems start to show up.Charming though it may be, the game has multiple issues ranging from save-games not loading properly, to certain game modes not functioning. There are major slow-downs in the game, and often your AI will become stuck doing nothing, for seemingly no reason.The beautiful structures you see in the screenshots are nearly impossible to build in the game's current state. (No, seriously, how in the heck did they make those?)Development is also insanely slow, if it's even progressing at all.Make no mistake, there is nothing even nearly complete about the game as it is now. I want to like the game, it shows a lot of promise, and it LOOKS fun; but with issues that haven't been fixed in literally years, and no sign of forward movement, you're much better off saving your money for a different game.IF things change in the future, I will happily update my review.

Early Access Review
								I was an original Kickstarter backer from about 3-years ago.  I was very disappointed in the development of new content prior to steam and for the past year I hadn't paid much attention to Castle Story until I happen to notice that 0.5 was released and appears to incorporate some new content.  I figured it had probably been a year or more since I last checked in so I'd give it another go.Upon booting up the game, I noticed there were some new maps which made me think perhaps maybe they had finally gotten their act together and started producing content.I started off chopping down some trees so I had a place to stockpile resources.  I had remembered from a year ago when I last played that they came up with a horrible horrible user interface.  News flash, it's still there and it's my opinion that they somehow managed to make it even more complicated.  I simply, without a doubt, absolutely hate the interface they've come up with.After creating a few dozen zones to allow my minions to place resources, I decided to start doing some mining to collect rock/stone as well.  I sent off four of the five minion to work on the side of a hill while my remaining unit cleaned up the rest of the trees and made some barrels for later.About 10 minutes later, all my miners went stupid and were just standing there.  I moved them away from the hill, then assigned them to mining the hill again, which they happily did until 5 minutes later when they went stupid and forgot what they were supposed to be doing again.I instructed the minion away from the hill again, lets them regroup and sent them back to mining the hill again.  After 5 minutes, brain dead again.  Apparently the game still has some very serious pathing issues that have yet to be resolved.Right click, delete local content.I guess I’ll check back in a few years when 0.6 comes out.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								Although in its current state it is a pretty interesting game, it will likely not change in the next few years. In two years, there has been two mentionable updates, both of which brought either tiny features, (such as pillars) game breaking bugs (such as the assumed memory leak in the unstable build which forces you to reload the level every ten minutes) or both. I understand creating games is not easy, even through easy methods, such as game making or scripting programs, but this seriously makes me wonder if they are actually doing any development, or just making YouTube videos to say they are. I doubted Starbound, and they barely pulled through once, but this is far more problematic than slow development; this is avoidance. My suggestion is to put it on your wishlist, wait about five years, and check again. By that time you will maybe know its fate. I apologise for my straightforwardness.Edit 09 08 (Aug) 15The game in its current state is unplayably difficult. Using several different tactics I haven't been able to get past wave 4. The enemy is more powerful, spawns faster and has less chance of friendly-fire, and outnumbers you significantly. Time to go edit the map again, this is an interesting game if you can get past the lack of updates, the bugs (most of which are fixed more recently) and the now outrageous difficulty.

I really want these developers to improve it and hopefully some day the original dream comes true with Castle Story.For right now I cannot recommend Castle Story.  I strongly recommend that others wait and see how future development proceeds.  One day if I see significant improvements I promise to revise my review and give it a thumbs up.  In spite of being upset about backing Castle Story I really do want these developers to realize their original dream and be successful.  The project was funded in late August of 2012 and I'm wondering why things seem to proceed at such a slow pace.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								Just don't buy this. There are thousands of better things to do with $20 than buying this game. Buying this game is the same as giving $20 to the begger on the street that leeches on working people and gets drunk every night. You gain nothing from giving them $20 and society gets nothing from giving them $20. Do not do it.These guys don't work like you and I work for our boss. These guys are the kind that were making Duke Nukem Forever for 20years and still ended up with nothing.It's very unlikely they are trying to make the game but are the most incompetent people ever. Very likely they are sitting around the office all day playing their Xbox and eating pizza. I don't know how they aren't disgusted with themselves but having millions of dollars from sales in your pocket probably helps a lot.- The developers are so bad at their job that the first alpha released worked better than the first alpha they brought to Steam. And the current version on Steam works even worse than the first. The game development is going backwards. I know how crazy this sounds yet I'm saying the words with truth.- All 3years of development so far have been a struggle with making the core of the game. Basic functions are still not completed and many features like remapping keys or full options screen or a working AI pathfinding are still not in the game.They use Unity3D and all basic game features that you can imagine are nothing more than importing an asset store package and 15min configuration to build it into your own game. These guys fail at using a wizard that has 200 tutorial videos about on youtube. Literally!Anyone with the capacity to work in a game engine can rebuild to the current state of the game within a month. I know.- Their artist is working as hard as the rest of the team. All characters and props can be made in 2 weeks after viewing a few hours of Blender tutorials. Everything is modelled and textured extremely simple. You'd think after 3 years they would have more than 1 spruce tree, 1 yellow guy, 1 kind of grey rocks and 1 kind of wood beams/planks? You'd think there would be beaches and mountain ranges and dessert maps etc?- About a year ago they must have noticed buyers were catching on to their scam. So they hired some guy to full time censor the forums and delete any negative thread and ban any user that speaks any kind of bad about the game. Meanwhile all the new buyers who still genuinly think this game will ever be finished get smoothtalked how busy everyone is and how they have plans to fix and remake everything. After months when that deadline has come and gone, they invent a new deadline.TLDR: The people from Sauropod are scum.If you don't believe me, just scroll down the reviews and you can see that nothing I am saying is a lie. These guys are scammers, will shut you up any way they can and Valve is so out of touch with their customers that they don't react to thousands of complaints.

								I advise agaisnt buying this game (at least in its current state). It has been over 2 years since I purchased this game and there has been no new content added aside from temporary holiday bits. I suggest waiting for the full game if it ever happens. Over the course of the last 2 years, Castle Story has just recently claimed it will add a new map. Yes, 2 years for a map (and it isn't even available as of writing this). This game has potential, but the developers are not delivering. To help understand, here is a complete list of what has been accomplished with the game (minus bug fixes and balancing) for the past 2 years. content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								After backing this game based on its promise, it has turned out to be a huge disappointment thanks to the continous bugs and the complete and total lack of anything even vaguely resembling progress.Every time I find myself of a mind or in a mood to play it, I go and look for updates only to find they have at best released a handful of minor bugfixes, usually for bugs they created with their last major patch. No new content, no new levels, none of the mechanics that were originally promised, nothing. No multiplayer, no story mode, no maps or map editor...And I'm not talking about every few days or even weeks. This is totally the type of game I really WANT to play, it seemed like it had the potential. Originally, I *did* check up on it on a regular basis. But after continous disappointment, particularly when I *would* see an update on Steam and get my hopes up, only to find it was nothing of interest... I lost interest. Now several months go by before I even bother, and yet, still then, there's nada. Nichts. Zilch.And my interest in the game, despite it's potential, despite the fact that it SHOULD be the kind of game I'd love, my interest is basically the same as the game's development pace, which is to say, next to non-existent. Actually, the very fact that it has inspired me to go out of my way to write what is for me a rare negative review should say it all. I have no idea what they do over there at Sauropod Studios, but it most certainly isn't anything remotely like what I'd call "work", I can only assume that they've happily taken the $700k they made off the Kickstarter and are laughing at us all the way.EDIT: The developers CLAIM the game will be "released" at the end of the year. IF that happens and we actually get what we were promised in the Kickstarter, I will revist this review at that time. Until then, I simply cannot recommend this game based on the progress we have seen in the 3 years since it was supposed to release in the first place.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								I saw Castle Story on Kickstarter back in 2012 and wished I could have kick-started it, the concept was new and interesting, the graphics looked fresh and pretty and it looked like a fun game that would go somewhere. Well, 4 years down the line it still looks exactly like it did 4 years ago on that Kickstarter page.As far as I see, there is no real 'gameplay' to it other than plan a castle, dig some quarry's or mines and then watch the little yellow dudes AI fail to get it them the build zone or even properly drop resources off.Instead, you'll spend your game time watching your workers swap resources around with one another rather than building anything. It almost seems like they tried to implement a bucket brigade AI... which would work great if they gave the poor little workers a little more logic so they didn't run the exact same path when on the same task - because they then spend more time swapping resources between themselves and 'finding paths to blueprint' instead of running over there.The problems around building make it really hard to even attempt the 'wave survival' game modes - because its takes so long to get a simple wall around it and the damage enemies do (even on easy) wipes out your meagre combat units really quickly (I survived 60 kills ~8 waves before losing but still didn’t even have a simple wall up because the yellow dudes couldn't decide or work out how to get places)The final straw for me was putting 6 workers on a large build task. They'd keep stopping at the build site, even though there were plenty of resources and lots of room for movement. They just all kept saying they were going to the same pile of resources which I can only assume meant all 6 of their poor little AI's were clashing and blocking one another... without anyone actually moving!Some bullet points of what bugged me the most (Version 0.5.1):- The UI is terrible. Every action in-game relies on a right click and hold - it's not intuitive, it’s not clear and it’s not even explained to you. I had to go find a video tutorial on basic camera movement and building because it was so annoyingly unclear. Actions should speak for themselves and not have to be searched for.- Speaking of UI, sorting what materials can be placed on a storage pad is ridiculous. If you want to make it specifically wood, it takes 5 right click, hold, and selects to set it so. You need a lot of storage, so multiply that by the number of space you want... it’s just plain silly.- For a game about building castles its surprising tedious to build anything in (let alone a castle), you need more workers to get things done faster but the more workers you have the slower the build goes because they spend time bumping into one another and sometimes they just decide to have a stop work meeting.- The game constantly lags and has miniature seizures for a few seconds every few seconds...- As outlined, the AI is just shoddy. There are a few simple things that would make it miles more efficient... the best being a complete overhaul of their path-finding algorithm and how they interact with one another (not swapping resources every damn time they bump into each other!)- The game could benefit from a 'speed up time' button... a lot.Overall: 3/10Just so much wasted potential.Avoid at all costs - don't be fooled! There are better games out there!

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
Early Access Review
								My complete thoughts on this title. Basically, castle story is a very unique game that has a ton of potential. Although people beleive its very similar to games like towns, its completely different. Altough the objective of castle story is to protect your base from ememys and buils structues, its thought on survival is really weak, There're no food or water meters for your little minions, and the whole idea of 'crafting' is completely useless. Despite this, the game is actually fun to play, but can only be played for short amount of hours at a time, as its very repetative. You will always find yourself either building, chopping tree's or mining. Thats pretty much it, untill you have to fight a small amount of enemys day-by-day. Its area of land is also very small and limited, but as i said, it can be fun to play, and its still in Early Access, so what can you expect? So, is this game worth $20? Probably not, if im honest. Although fanboys may disagree, and cliaming that 'its only in early development and more will come', we should really expect more from these types of games, expecially if people are laying down $20 for a game that could have been made by a college student. Overall, if you're on the wall with this game, save the cash, and wait till more has been added. Not much to do, and not much fun overall. Infact the only thing that will keep you playing is the graphics.

content:
Posted: January 3
Early Access Review
								I tried playing this game again after two years. My first impression of the game was it was absolute trash. Here is what you need to know.Pros:1.Fun concept.2. Combat is longer than before.3. Developers are being more active than previous years.Cons:1. While the bricktons do work together, they will simply all get stuck once you get more than three doing a task. 2. Catapaults are completely broken. I was not able to change targets after selecting one area it would only fire in that one spot regardless. Better make that one area really count since you can't deconstruct anything.3. Your brickton spawning is either capped, or gets bugged and you cannot create more bricktons. 4. Development is incredibily slow. However, the studio seems to be picking up the pace as of late. This game has been in early access for at least 4 years as of now.5. The game performance is absolutely atrocious. After playing a match for an hour, my fps would jump from 1 fps to 45-60 after capping it at 60. The ratio of dropped frames was about 1fps for 8 seconds for 20 seconds of 45-60fps. This is my high tier pc here are my specs. i7-6700 @ 4.0Ghz 16gb ddr4 @ 3200Titan X (pascal)1tb hdd (wd blue)Conclusion: While I really want this game to come to fruition, it still has a lot of work to go. I wouldn't recommend purchasing the game in it's current state. The game needs optimization and bugfixing before I would recommend ANY one from buying this game. If I am getting the game to @ 1fps imagine the average joe pc. TL:DR:This game has still has broken core mechanics, game ruining bugs, horrid optimization, broken pathfinding. I absolutely would not recommend this game currently as of January 2, 2017. After note:I'll try again in another two years.

number of helpful: 35 of 43 people (81%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								After a year or so of not playing Castle Story, I recently came back to it and soon ran into a new patch which broke the game for me. I decided to wait a few weeks for them to fix it — the one that froze the game with constant lag after about an hour and a half of playing the same map, and when you reach a certain number of people. Over a month later, there is still no fix.(As of the 26th of June, I have tested the latest patches... it's still going on)When I add that situation to how long this game has taken in the past, until now, to actually have updates implemented, I have to give this one a rather big no for my recommendation. This game has so much potential, and I mean a lot, but there is definitely an issue with the very slow development team, and the lack of progress made when an update is actually released — not much has actually been implemented long term, and important parts of the game are still disabled by the developers because they don't work properly (such as digging). I follow a lot of early access games and this is the poorest development cycle I am aware of at the moment.  Negatives (As of June 2015 with 'bleeding edge' version)-The way the UI is set-up for building, placing items, etc, is atrocious. You have to drill down through so many selections to reach what you want to reach, then you have to get back out if you want to do something else.. it's a bit like torture.  (This is the worst thing about the game for me)-The Save/Load menu is bulky, and slow to use. This needs polishing. (small issue though)-Very slow progression with the development of the game-The radius with cutting down trees. You have to keep adding 'flags' every time you want to cut down a group of trees, and this is rather tedious. -Major performance issues when reaching a certain number of people on screen -The way blue crystal is put into crates by default (again, tedious to manually move it to the actual blue crystal)-The lack of maps on survival. There needs to be a variety here based on peoples play styles, such as a corner start, instead of in the middle. This would greatly improve the game for a lot of people.-The waves(enemies) come too fast. There needs to be an option to manage waves before beginning the game-The fact you have to place a clean up broom radius flag… they should just clean up automatically, or the stuff that needs cleaning up should disappear over time. (tedious to manage, and the little bits littering the ground slow the game down)Positives (As of June 2015 with 'bleeding edge' version)-Friendly fire, but this can get annoying (needs fine tuning)-Variety of enemies (needs fine tuning)-The types of structures you can build using stone or wood. This is rather fun and is really the main point of the game. -The cuteness of the game. The yellow guys and the grey guys are all very cute and make cute noises.-Having your archers take out the enemy is rather enjoyable once you have enough of them, and a system in place where you know exactly where to place them, and how to build your defences. -The quick response of the developers to forum posts is very supportive & commendable-The music is quite good, but there needs to be more variety.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is nearly unplayable due to bugs that should have been dealt with three years ago. At it's core, Castle Story is an experimental survival/sandbox RTS in which you tell little yellow guys called Bricktrons what to do. They can work or fight, but typically get confused while carrying out their assigned tasks and just stop doing anything. The bugs in this WiP game are just too much, considering the fact that it's been 'in beta' for four years now. The project is obviously too much for the 10-man, part-time, on-again-off-again development team, and it's gotten to the point that they've hired on a PR guy to try in vain to dispel the rumors that this game has crumbled to nothing. Updates are infrequent, and the ones that come every four to six months add no new content, and fix none of the bugs which make the game almost unplayable. Box, if you're reading this, I'm sorry for you, and what the company you're representing is doing to you, and to the Kickstarter backers of this game. 1/5

content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've owned this for over like 3 years and I backed it in the Kickstarter and had super high hopes for Castle Story but I felt really ripped off when I finally got to play the 'early access'. It looked absolutely nothing like in the trailers or demos that we were given a lot of previews of. I followed development really closely and I felt like the dev team at times were really ignorant of how the players felt about their 'progress' and 'attention' on certain aspects of the game.I made a thread on the forums with over 15 things that I could not find in the early access version of the game, vs all the demo videos they had shown. In the end I got the response I was expecting. Nothing.In the beginning you were actually advised by the devs to enable the cheats console to even use the game properly.Certain sounds were bugged so badly like background 'crickets' that were looped really loudly and never stopped and couldn't be silenced without muting the whole game.Entire 'building bricks' that were in the demos were missing. These were small things that were missing for ages.There were no enemies for close to a year.The menu, even years after the early access was released, is still terrible and so unintuitive.For 2 years after the game was available to play, there wasn't any multi-player at all.It took a year just to get the choice to start off on a different map from that only single one the game shipped with.Development blogs and transparency from the devs went from being something they would write about and share with their players weekly, to where you wouldn't hear from them for months despite people paying for early-access (funding them).AI was so bugged and 'bricktons' would just randomly stop what they were doing or get stuck so easily.Performance on a good machine was absolutely terrible for over a year.All in all, for the amount of money they raised on Kickstarter and the speed at which they went to early access, the game was one of the most disappointing in its early stages, that I had ever seen. In the end this game in particular taught me to never purchase an 'early-access' game because the sheer lack of development progress the game can be on, and still be allowed to be released on Steam is just ridiculous.I really wanted to like this game, but I feel that development has shifted so many times due to the incompetent team. Also in mid 2015 almost no one plays this game. All Youtube videos are from 2-3 years ago when the game still had some 'hype' let alone some 'hope' surrounding it. Little has changed since then except that now the game has less bugs and could be considered something that doesn't need to be in 'early access'. This doesn't change the fact that the game simply isn't fun for me, and that the controls and UI and menus are still terrible. Basically the developers have totally missed their deadline in terms of it getting popular.It's not remotely worth €25 and it probably won't be for another 2 years. It's a huge shame too because the graphics and potential this game has is absolutely through the roof. Hopefully in a few more years I will be able to recommend it, that is, if development is even on going and if people even play it.P.S. I know my review isn't very 'consistent' but you can't expect that when development on this game has been about as inconsistent as it gets.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								I was very excited for this game. I was actually convinced to buy this game a year ago because a friend had it and wanted to try the multiplayer. We tried forever to get the mutiplayer to work, but it never did, and the devs eventually locked it. Its been like that for a long time. I never wrote a review about the game because I hoped it would get better. It never did. The game is still plauged with problems and has been in early access for at least a year and a half. That seems like plenty of time to actually get something done, right? Nope. I noticed almost no difference in the game when I played today in comparason to the day I bought it (End of 2013) The only things that seemed different were that they had iron and annoying curruptions that took forever to kill. The game still feels like a buggy mess when I play. Constantly my workers glitch and stop working or listening to commands. Ive seen them complain that they cant reach blocks right in front of them. They bunch up in 2 block wide hallways and I constantly have my guys shot by archers. My warriors dont listen and attacking is annoying because its hard to click on the guy you want to kill. Sometimes guys stand there and die because they glitch out. Some glitches have to be fixed by reloading the save and gets annoying when you have to do it every 30-60 minutes. The game also suffers from screen tearing. My NVEDIA 880M and Intel I7 4710HQ@3.50GHz have trouble running this game because the game refuses to use them to their full power. The highest ive seen my GPU usage go in this game is 40% and the CPU 50%. Mostly the game uses around 10-20% of my GPU and 30-40% of my CPU and my ram hovers around 9GB (Out 0f 32) Since the game refuses to use my gpu or cpu the framrate is terrible. When I get into a game the framerate is great. But it quickly drops and then hits around 1-2 FPS with gpu usage at 1-10% and CPU at 10-20%. I know you have to click the delete key but even then the game hovers around 30-40FPS with 20-30% gpu usage and 30-40% cpu usage. I dont have a cap on frames either. In an attept to fix the screen tearing I lowered the graphics to fastest and went to NVEDIA control panel and turned on VSYNC. Frame rate was still the same even though my GPU was 1-10% and CPU was still 20-30%. On my old computer I had in 2013 (It had a NVEDIA 230M and an I7 cpu with 8GB of ram) the framrate never went below 120FPS and stayed near 200FPS when the game started and I had full GPU and CPU usage. It seems to me that this problem has come recently. The sreen tearing is ugly and basically is the final nail in the coffin for this game. Most of the graphical problems arrise when the GPU usage goes down to below 20%. Setting the game to High Priority does not even help. My GPU is not crap either. For some perspective I can run GTA 50FPS with everything at very high except water (High) and shadows (High) with MSAA on and tessalation off. My resolution is 2560X1440p too so its quite impressive and the game looks great. When playing GTA gpu usage is at 98% and CPU is at 70-90%. In short the graphical problems come when the GPU is used at its lowest and I could ignore the bugs if it was not for the horrendus screen tearing and FPS that slowley drops over time. What sucks even more is that when you join a world at wave 10 the framrate starts at 60 and then drops to 10-20 over a period of 2 minutes and its not because there is stone everywhere. I constantly remove the stone by hitting delete.

Early Access Review
								 Castle Story was a fun concept tied around a modestly appealing, simplistic art style. And before anybody locks to this review for being negetive, let me explain. I don't dislike this game, but it's simply under-developed and shows very little ammounts of progress. The cons far out way the pros, but I will be more than happy to change this review once it finishes. (IF it finishes.)Pros:-Voxel system-Cool graphical style-It's like if Minecraft was simplified and made into an RTSCons:-The AI is dreadfuly stupid-Path finding is about as bad as you could get without the bots standing completely still (which they will often do)-Optimization? This game, even on the lowest graphical settings, will at random, draw to a halt. Freezing and stuttering like your computer is a toaster-Lots of bugs, unresponsive AI, can't cut down a tree without it tumbling off the side of the map into oblivion, ect-It's like if Minecraft was simplified and made into an RTS I really do wanna see this game get further along, but such a slow development process is leaving me with little hope it'll ever get out of early access. (Although multiplayer was finally added in recently.) I won't hold my breath for this game.TL:DR early access at its finest. 4/10(PS: Could be a good 5-6 as is were the AI not so bad.)(PPS: To the developer: Please work on this. It's a great concept, and shouldn't be left to die.)

content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								It pains me to write this, especially as one who managed to get some enjoyment out of this title, as well as someone who bought the game barely a month after it was put up on Steam with high hopes. Castle Story is a lackluster and at times needlessly frustrating experience that will just make you want to crave more with no hope of it ever delivering. First of all, the AI remains dirt stupid and at times unresponsive, making mutlitasking, an element crucial to games like these, more arduous than it should be. Sandbox mode will most likely not hold your attention for long, with there being a limited variety in building materials. Not only that, but getting said materials is time consuming and tedious, something you don't want said about a supposed sandbox mode. Survival mode seemed promising at first, combining the freedom to build structures of many shapes and sizes with a tower defense play-style. Now, there is fun to had here if you're willing to look past the bad AI and hardly any strategy. Otherwise, the novelty won't save it from the mediocrities riddled throughout this gamemode. Accompanied with the aforementioned AI problems, the guards will ignore oncoming enemies, letting them slip by and wreak havok on your settlement. It's a shame because this gamemode has the potential to be something fufilling, if it were just executed better and had more options at your disposal (i.e, leveling up bricktrons and contraptions, stronger materials, depth in level design). With no other gamemode to fall back on, you are almost guaranteed to lose interest long before this ever leaves early-access. You'd think that the developers would have found the time to encorporate more features and gamemodes in the last two years or so to keep us interested, much like many other open-alpha indie games out there. But alas, for whatever reason, updates have mainly consisted of bug fixes and graphical improvements. Unless by some miracle, this game gets finished and has a solid, replayable, and satisfying experience as a final product, I doubt I'll be concerning myself with this game anytime soon, and I suggest you do the same, to anyone thinking of buying this.

number of helpful: 23 of 28 people (82%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								OK, so a while back I did a review on this game. I still said it was positive, but I basically said "It's buggy but it'll get better". And now I feel is the time to re-review it.Let me start off by saying this is one of the coolest and prettiest castle builders I've seen in a long while. It has a near perfect arrangement of blocks to suit all of your construction needs, yet it simultaniously keeps you materials as basic as possible. You can build with Stone, or Wood. There are a few other materials that can be used to make useful structures, but those are the two things your castle is really gonna be made of. Yet in that simplicity, you can make very cool-looking castles with ease. And what's even cooler is that in the survival gamemodes, all of the castles you built for purpose and purpose alone still turn out looking amazing. So let's talk about how you build castles. Basically, you have little yellow blobby units called "bricktrons", which you have to tell what to do. This can consist of mining, cutting trees, building your castle, repairing damages, etc. Getting them to do these things is very simple. Want to build something? Create a construction task, place blueprints, and assign bricktrons to the task, they do the rest. The way they go about building these things still isn't the best... but it gets the job done.Then there's combat. So there's two survival gamemodes: Invasion, and conquest. Conquest has you go and capture crystals, and invasion has you defend against infinitely increasing waves of enemies. But both will have you be fighting 3 enemies: Little corruptrons, medium corruptrons, and big corruptrons. Not the most original lineup, but bare with me here. Anyway these 3 classes will act exactly like you expect. Little ones are fast, and big ones are slow but deadly. You have 3 ways of killing them. Warrior bricktrons with swords, Archer bricktrons, or catapults. In my opinion, the combat is probably one of the weaker points of the game, especially now that they nerfed your warriors. So the waves can get unfairly difficult, and you absolutely need a catapult. But even then, it's hard to learn how to lead your shots. It's not bad per say, but just be aware this game can get pretty brutal.Real quick I'll talk about the visuals, they are just shy of a masterpeice! Fantastic texture work, a great lighting engine, dynamic shadows on the higher settings, and they did a great job of bumpmapping everything. Unfourtunately the frames can take a dip at times, and there's no real particle affects, so the distance can look a bit ugly.And I'll be honest, the game still has some bugs. It still crashes from time to time (though it's not really all that bad) Bricktrons can have some quirky pathfinding at times, and they for some reason really want to place blocks they can't reach. Which really bothers me. Also, sometimes your knights will refuse to retreat when you tell them to, and just get pummeled. Which, again, can get very troublesome. I would advise saving regularly if you plan on playing survival.But this game absolutely oozes charm and love. As you build your castle you grow attatched to both it, and your little bricktron minions. (For example there was one moment where I had gotten a builder stuck, so I killed him with my catapult. And that genuinley made me sad.) You start seeing your castle as the home of these little guys, and every once in a while, you pan your camera down, see all your bricktrons working, see the gorgeous lighting and shadows, as well as the majesty of your castle, and your immediately reminded why you play this game.So, should you buy it? It depends. You can't speed up time (and for good reason, optimizing that would be nightmare for anyone) so you'll be waiting a while as your bricktrons slowly build up your castle. For me, this further strengthens the bond between me and what I've built, because I sit there thinking about how much time I've put into it. But some people aren't as patient and will get bored. Which I'm sure is where some of the more recent negative votes come from. (And some people are saying it's to complicated... what? This is as simple as they come... you wanna see a complex sandbox game, go look at Dwarf Fortress!) So ask yourself these questions:1: Are you a sentimental person?2: Are you patient?3: Can you deal with a few rough edges?If you answered no to any of those questions, then I'd say castle story either isn't for you, or maybe you should wait a little longer for more updates.

								You never know what you are going to get when you buy into an Early Access game. Sometimes you help fund the next gem of a game, like Prison Architect, who probably wouldn't have had the capital to make such a game if it weren't for EA, but on the other hand, sometimes your money gets flushed into the eternal purgatory that is commonplace in EA and you never get your money back, The Dead Linger. No, the makers haven't thrown in the towel yet, but there really hasn't been much improvement in the past year, content or performance wise. Early Access Review
								Ok first of all i am one of the few OS X users.I tried to give this game a chance I really did but its horrible in its current state. It's performance is appalling and my system is far better than the specs listed below, I can run CS:GO (On my other account) maxed out at 120 fps in a full on firefight. But this game I'm lucky to get more than 10 frames while the camera is standing still on "simple graphics".(Graphic settings; Fastest, Fast, Simple, Good, Beautiful, Fantastic.)Then its ridden with game breaking bugs. Before you say "It's in early access it's not supposed to be bug free." this game's alpha came out over a YEAR ago(Proof 


YouTube™ Video:  

			Views: 0		



. And there's barely anything to even do in this game even tho its been in development for well over a year now.	Heres a rundown of what you can do in the game currently. Play Hard or Normal survival or sandbox mode and a Multiplayer Arena mode. You only have the ability to do these three single player game modes on a single map(Arena mode has 4 tiny little islands apart from each other.). Once playing one of those game modes you have to get Stone from a mine in survival(By digging in sandbox) for building Blocks, half Blocks, stairs, and stone Arches. Then you have to get wood for Barrels, Columns, Platforms, Catapults, Stockpiles, Doors, Torches, and ladders. When in survival you have to fight off endless waves of (I’ve only gotten to wave 5 so don’t truly know if they stop a certain point past that.) Bricktons with your choice of archer or knight.(Can build as many of each as you want if you have the required resources) The way to spawn more is you have to collect blue crystals in the mine and them put them in a barrel near your “Home crystal”. And there you go thats everything you can build and basically do in this game so far.NOT worth 20$ in my opinion now if you're looking for a game to just build something simple and boring looking then get this, but if you want to build some amazingly extraordinary Castle this is not the game.

number of helpful: 25 of 32 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								I have got this game for a long time. I did build a lot of castles, both in Survival/Invasion and Sandbox modes. I did not do much in the Conquest mode, even though it is fun as well. What I like and what is CS good at: Being a civil engineer I love the construction aspect: you can really build amazing castles and see how they stand against invasion waves of enemy hordes. Or you can build a set of defensive walls and trenches with towers. You can do a combination of those. The choice is yours and you can see your strategy either fail or succeed. It is kind of like the tower defence games but in 3D with real structural physics where you have to think it trough and then build it up brick by brick. I always enjoyed constructing buildings and structures in Minecraft. And this gives you another aspect: combat level.You also have to set up archers and knights around and organize them in the most effective manner because this game is not forgiving. This game had some issues in past. I think it had developed well from those "dark ages" and is now very well playable giving players lots of fun, with even more to come in future.What I dislike: Friendly fire: the archers sometimes hit their own, knights are too weak (in version 0.6x). Sometimes it has to be reloaded due to stuck or unresponsive bricktrons.Final word: I do enjoy this game but is it good for you as well? Do you like building castles and defences? Do you like strategy thinking how to protect your area? Do you like games with combat and some basic resource management? If yes this game is for you too.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've been following Castle Story since the very early days, backing it well before the jump to Steam, and excitedly looking forward to every dev blog and update. As the years went on, I was less and less optimistic about outcome of the game, and until recently, this would have been a very different review.Looking at the game now (as of 0.7) I can confidently recommend Castle Story. It's been a long and often bumpy road, and I've been critical of some of the decisions made in the development process. However, there is no doubt in my mind as to the dedication and tenacity of the dev team, and now I believe they have the ability to match that dedication, and will bring Castle Story fully to its intended vision.

number of helpful: 22 of 27 people (81%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								Although there is a disclaimer before buying this game as "early access", it should be a disclaimer of "barely started".  The game mechanics are clunky and the AI is poorly written.  This game began as a kickstarter project in July of 2012.  At the time it was $25 to back the game and earn early access.  The company, Sauropod Studio, was seeking $80,000 to produce the game.  Kickstarters provided the developers with around $700,000.  In March of 2013 a prototype was released.  As of January of 2014 the game remains in prototype stage and the company developers have stated they are continuing to work on the game with no timetable for completion. Adding insult to injury, the game is now available as "early access" on Steam for $19.99, less than the original Kickstarter package.  This game is a promising concept but remains only a concept as the Sauropod Studios has stagnated in it's overall development of the game.At this time I do not recommend buying the game, but waiting until full release if the game ever reaches that point.

Early Access Review
								It never ceases to amaze me how harsh the critics are about an unfinished project. I backed this game on Kickstarter because it looked awesome: like a strategy/city-builder with Minecraft elements. So far, the game remains unfinished and very difficult (pro-tip: get some archers and have your knights run in circles leading the big Corruptrons around town). The have delivered a framework on which the game can be built, even if the mechanics need some tweaking. The developer emails kickstarter backers about once a month with updates. Around Halloween each year, they add "spooky" elements to the characters. If you generally find yourself hating Early Access games, wait until it's published. Early Access means it's not quite done yet, so don't judge it based on the criteria you use on a completed game. The developers are probably too busy developing to answer your idiotic questions. Be patient, or play something else.
