Early Access Review
								Castle story has the potential to be amazinng but, at the moment, it isn't. The bricktons were very unresponsive, at least for me, and I found it quite boring. There is no tutorial and you have to go into the menu to even find out that some of the most important features in the game even exist. For the first half of my time spent on this game I found myself restarting over and over gain because the building system is flawed, there is no way to undo specific bricks in walls if you make a mistake as far as I can discern and placing even one single brick in the wrong place while laying foundations means that you have to do the whole thing over again. At the moment there is only one map that you can play on and the world editor is disabled. If you do get this game you'll probably end up covering your entire floating island in stockpiles. The game has a lot of pottntial but is held back by some of its own mechanics. The fact that it is based on floating islands looks cool but the game would be much better if it was in a randomly generated non floating world. Do not get it YET.

number of helpful: 20 of 24 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								The only way to describe this game is "dreadful and unfinished". If this were on a physical CD, we'd call it a coaster.I'm a KS backer and purchased this based on the concept and the movies. The game looked great, the art style was cute and the promised finished date was October 2012. It looked like a very cute sandbox building game with your minions running around mining, woodcutting and building a cute fortress to protect your guys with blueprints and such. It was, and is, a great concept. Execution has been a different issue...Here we are two years later and there's been little progress made and even less communication. While someone like Box may talk on the forums, they simply don't communicate. There is no roadmap which has been requested for the last year. Dev diaries are fluff pieces devoid of any real information. The refactoring process brought no apparent improvements because the promised content releases after it was done have not materialized. In short, the project is a disaster and borders on scammy. So what has been delivered? A prototype with awful UI, stupid AI and hasn't had an appreciable update in a year. The survival and multiplayer modes that have been supposedly added don't work. The UI is beyond horrid - even simple tasks don't work well because the UI is so cumbersome. It's like the devs decided to throw out every decent UI convention in the last decade and come up with the most obtuse system they could. You'll spend hours just trying to learn how to issue simple commands to your guys and learning to control the camera. The AI is just plain broken and even the devs admit it. And again, there haven't been any real content updates in the last year either. I can't stress this enough - what has been delivered is so devoid of content it's not a game. It's a prototype demo with horrible UI, horrible AI and by a developer who seems entirely incapable of finishing their product. As such, there is no way to recommend this game. Stay far, far away. I would normally say "check back later", but here we are two years after the promised release date and it's still virtually vaporware. At this point I've written this game off as a total loss, but hopefully by reading this you can save your money and buy something that may actually provide some entertainment and value because Castle Story won't.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								Castle Story has been in development for well over a year and in that time not a large amount of progress has been made. However with that being said I believe there is real promise with this game, all be it if it gets finished! There are some things which make it very unique and some which make it mainstream.Pros:- Unique Art Style- Interesting style of gameplay- Enjoyable for Short - Medium play times (1-3 Hours)- Survival is very promising Cons: - Quite buggy in terms of the AI (AI often gets stuck with overloaded orders and enemy can often find pathing difficult)- Variety of units is very limited (Melee Warrior/Archer/Builder:Unarmed)- Limited Gamemodes- Very basic Tutorial (Controls are very simple but was lack of proper tutorial, can be frustrating)- Limited building options (2x2 Block | 1X1 Block | Arch Block | Wooden Pillar | Wooden Plank)- Time period of development is worrying (Over a year and not a large amount of progress)- Pricing (£15/$20) Is very constly for an almost Alpha/Beta Overall the game is fun to play for a Short/Medium amount of time however given the number of issue's addressed above  I would hold off buying it untill there is improvement or unless it is discounted down to around £4-8/$12. However because of these issues I would have to rate it probably a 4/5 out of 10!

content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've had this game since April of last year and still can't get it to work how it was intended to. Quick list of negatives:- The AI are unresponsive and take so much patience - and in a mode such as survival, you cannot afford the sometimes minutes it takes for some AI to 'think'.- Updates are almost nonexistant, I returned just today after a few months of not playing just to see the changes equivalent to that of a single update in a 'normal' game. - Multiplayer is barren. I have yet to find any servers, and I feel this is more a fault of the developers rather than the community with the huge negative feedback they have received. - Recently, the tutorial seems to be absent. Quick list of positives: + The GUI is really beautiful - all so clean cut and accessible, with features within are organized wonderfully.+ A great concept, I think, especially for PvP or co-op multiplayer gameplay. Altough I've never seen PvP, or any multiplayer mode for that matter, the idea sounds wonderful.+ A great selection of different building pieces, opening a wide range of possible constructs to defend your 'Bricktrons'.This game is something I think everyone that came here wanted to badly to love; I denied the numbers of negative reviews when I purchased the game, but honestly I don't believe it was a mistake. Although, that may just be my want to love it talking. If I ever see any actual involvement of the developers, I might recommend it. Just don't forget about this game.

								Its been a long road but it was worth it in the end. I do not think the game is 100% complete by any means but it certainly has been worth the wait if your like me and like playing single player sandbox, I love the big world as it gives you a lot more choices of what you can do and how you can do it, if you can work out how the blocks work :).The A.I presently is sweet doing mostly everything that i would want them to do from digging along a plain and then going for the next layer of dirt or rock so they can gradually dig out the earth evenly, Today i tried to play for a couple of hours but my computer and the house decided that today was not my day (blackout) to play but i got my testing that i wanted, I have been testing the game on the largest world possible because it means i can stress test the game to what i think is a reasionable test. Things like flatting out an area, building on that flat area up a crooked moutain and all the while making sure the game hasn't got its niggles which are a few at this time.Just so i can point these out. There's a double effect going on with the A.I's behaviour it seems they will take a task and split it in half meaning if they get half way done they will re-aquire there path which to me isnt a bad thing. BUTTT it can pause the game very breifly and that is why i have stated the game isn't quite there just yet but its soo close its not funny.A feature the game needs is a Fast forward button to speed up work but i am not sure if that will ever be a thing in this game, The game is stable, Fun, Colorful, and long lasting at least for me if you like to play for long hours on end and watch your little bricktrons run about doing tasks you have set apon them.I am writing today on this review board because now is the time to do so, The dev's have been asking when i will do do one and i have always said that When the game is done or at least getting to a almost finnished product i will do one then, So the game is now worth your time for single player bases, And thats how this review is.So if you wish to get info for muliplayer this game has it along with caputre the flag and a couple of other modes in that, as well as single player being conquest where you get enemy's that attack you from different directions and you can try and survive by building a base and holding off the enemy.But i do not play that mode so please look to other for that information.Thank you Castle Story Dev's and I can't wait to see if you do anything else with this game.

number of helpful: 12 of 13 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								TLDR: Looks can be deceiving.At the time of writing, the game is only early access.  As usual, you shouldn't expect too much - the game will be glitchy and buggy, and my opinion of the game takes that into account.Castle Story is basically another sandbox dwarf-fortress-ish game that appears to take a different approach by using much simpler game mechanics.  You don't have to worry about needs such as food and water, but rather just focus on building a functional castle that can defend against attacks.What I like- It looks cool!  It's got the puffy white clouds, the very simple-looking avatars (bricktrons), the lego-like castle building blocks, etc.,- The gameplay is very simple, it has a refined-looking design, something that appeals to me.What I don't like- Although being early-access, the game is barely playable.  I tried really hard to enjoy the game, but couldn't.  I fully expect to find bugs in a beta, but this title is mostly all looks, the gameplay itself is very bad.- There's not much to do in the game - when I say there's not much to do, I mean what you see in those screens is about it.  You can build some stone and wood blocks, and that's about it.This game shouldn't be early access - it should've stayed out of Steam until it was much more ready than this.  The vibe I got after playing is that the developers - while they might mean well - are an inexperienced group desperately reaching for what funding they can get.Here's a good discussion thread for more info.  I came back to it recently to find it locked - which seemed quite unnecessary.  This is another bad sign imo:http://steamcommunity.com/app/227860/discussions/0/648814844593898025/#p10

								As a game developer who has actually worked extensively with Voxels and Unity, The amount of updates that this bunch pump out are pathetic. They always defend themselves with the 'refactoring' statement, and while that's fine, if the code is THAT BAD then they had it at a level that is not marketable in the slightest, like selling a car without wheels. The other excuse is the fact that there are only a few of them, only a few highly trained devs working on it. So what? You sold the product and should have the stones to support it. I've been waiting a long time for any hint of a decent update and just have been dissapointed. Give me a year and I could probably produce more. On my own, as a hobbyist.To sum it up in two words. Utterly Dissapointing.UPDATE : This game takes the cake

number of helpful: 12 of 14 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								SUBJECT TO CHANGEI've owned the game since at least October of last year, there have been few updates with no estimate of an official release. And prior to my purchase the game had been in pre-release status for I don't know how long, but apparently a decent amount of time. For a game that has so little to offer in terms of complexity it would be expected that the developers would work on cleaning up the code that they have to avoid lag build up from poorly constructed AI pathing loops, intense overlapping light bloom effects, and poor enemy spawning management (massive instant spawn of 1+ incrementing enemies that increase for each wave, each with their own poorly constructed pathing AI in a big mess of how long does it take your processor to figure out which one moves first). The development team seems to focus on cleaning up minor bugs and slowing down the process by adding new members to the team before they've even come close to working out game breaking kinks. As a warning by wave 100 or sooner this game will be nearly unplayable (due to FPS) for people without an average or above average computer, even on fastest graphics settings. Avoiding torches and lighting may help with some FPS drop.Granted the game is fun. Anyone that has no issues with repetitive gameplay and likes the concept of a kind of cross between RTS and Tower Defense games will probably enjoy this. Building a castle or structure that is tactical as you decide how you want to go about surviving increasing waves is pretty rewarding for people who would enjoy that, and the game offers a sandbox mode for players who don't want the interruptions that come with survival.Overall, the gameplay is good, but it almost feels like the development team doesn't intend to actually finish the game. Like people who run off with scholarship money, this is starting to feel like a scam to half make a game with lots of kinks, slowly update little stuff, and then run off after sales start falling. Not that it is, but this has to be the laziest studio I've ever waited for. It doesn't even have a game icon.Edit: RE: Developer comment and update.I have already, and that doesn't change the length of time that has and still is going into the project. Not to mention that the game is still poorly constructed. I just finished actually playing the update, it was cut short by me not being able to pause. By that I mean I had to save my game to go to the bathroom. Tried to load it and there's a fresh new bug that kills saves. Archers still friendly fire and destroy storage areas, the AI pathing is choppy and inefficient, and it seems like corners were cut by making workers able to move through storage instead of fixing the AI itself. Now I don't know if that was the intention because frankly I enjoy the playability of the change, it does boost player efficiency because the workers don't dogpile anymore. However, for many months and obviously before I bought the game all of the entities seem to suffer from intense short term memory loss and they just stand there day dreaming in a programming loop. This is persisting even after this new update and every update before it.My comment was harsh because this legitimately is the longest I've ever waited for a developing team to work out game breaking kinks, and I am going to remain harsh because so far the most noticeable changes have been graphical goodies for the seasons, a sound update, and minor bug fixes. There is nothing to re-evaluate, I'm a programmer too. If this were my project I'd address the major issues before working on redoing the sounds and giving people some holiday textures.To not be unfair in this I will say that the changes made the game a much better experience. Being able to store more orange crystal and not have the dogpiling issue is nice. It does free up time. The change to gatherers defaulting to the storage space with the most material already in it is noticeable.Now I have asked on the forums for some information about when certain issues are going to be fixed or if they are being taken into consideration. I didn't make this or my previous comment without giving a fair chance. I have been previously active on the main forum. I noticed a moderator that has a spider for a profile picture that gives people a hard time that aren't breaking any forum rules, and repetitive game complaints and suggestions that get little to no official response.For more information read comments:

content:

Early Access Review
								TLDR: Castle Story is a great Real Time Strategy Castle Defense game. I have been playing Castle Story off an on since it was released on Kickstarter. The game has come a long way since alpha. I would definitly recommend this game!Pros:+ Solid building mechanics+ Multiple Game Modes [Sandbox , Conquest, Invasion]+ Multiple enemy types+ Create your own Custom Maps+ Catapults and Explosions!Cons:- No Steam Multiplayer integration yet (use Hamachi or be on the same network)- No Steam Workshop support to share custom maps (can use CastleStory Forums)- Outdated tutorial, in need of an Advanced tutorial to explain more complex mechanics. Feature Wish List:---General---+ Steam Multiplayer and Server search+ Ability to create groups of Archers and groups of Warriors---Conquest---+ When mousing over a crystal, highlight which crystal it is in the Upper left UI.---Map Editor---+ Undo / Redo option+ Ability to asign Player Spawns to certain Team colors (for multiplayer Conquest mode)+ Option to enable automatic symmetry over the x/z axis

number of helpful: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								I know the thought process that goes behind buying a game like this. It LOOKS great, and it's only early access, so you're sure it's probably going to be great at some point. You've read negative reviews, and ignored them anyway. I did the exact same thing. I wish I had not.This game is an awesome concept. It has the potentially be beautiful, fun, and worth the money that I just wasted. But right now, it's hardly even qualified to be a Beta game. It's a mess, and I'm highly discouraged by the rate at which it is being updated. This game is essentially unplayable as-is, as it becomes very boring very quickly.As a game developer myself, I know how hard it is to create a working game, and how annoying it is when the audience does not understand all the work that must be put in to the final product. In this case, though, I feel like progress is practically inching along at the slowest pace possible, and a bug-ridden, unplayable, broken game was released to say 'Don't worry, we're doing something'.I cannot recommend purchasing this game right now. My advice is to keep an eye on it, because it's an awesome idea and it has so much potential (potential which it had better reach, given the 700k that was donated to it via Kickstarter), but you'll be disappointed if you blow your Steam budget on the current stage of this game (as of 1/2/2014)

number of helpful: 20 of 31 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								As of the latest patch, this is now a game. Using systems similar to Towns, Gnomeria, and Dwarf Fortress, you command your little yellow dudes to build castles, brick by brick, to defend against random monsters as you try to conquire floating islands. It's pretty simplistic but if you enjoy the Dwarf Fortress game type combined with base defense mechanics, this game will scratch an itch. It's still early stages but it has a lot of potential.It's rather unfortunate this game has so many negative reviews. It's in Early Access for a reason, the developers needed a lot of help to figure out in which direction the game should go to appeal to a bigger audience. As of the latest patch, the game is much better than it's ever been. I could actually understand most of the negative reviews for the earlier versions but, seriously, the game deserves a second chance. This is just another showing of how the Steam review system doesn't operate properly for Early Access games.

content:

Early Access Review
								It's a very fun game, but even my monster of a computer cannot handle it after a few nights. For nights 1-2, I'm getting a solid 60 fps. By night 5, that has dropped to maybe 10. If I save and quit, I'll get a small performance boost for a minute or two the next time I play, but then it becomes extremely jumpy again. There is some bug or leak in the code that just makes this game absolutely unplayable.I'm sure this would be a major hit, but the performance problem completely destroys it.

number of helpful: 15 of 22 people (68%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								While I get the frustration with waiting eons for a game's completion, there are clear indicators before purchasing that this game is incomplete. The game has bugs, but they're squashed relatively quickly thanks to a responsive and dedicated development team. The game could have more content, but your expectations should have been lowered when you saw this was early access. Plus the mechanics and gameplay are clean and, from watching earlier videos, have clearly been iterated on with care.I don't feel like I've been lied to by the devs about this game's state, and for an early access game I've had a tremendous amount of fun playing it. I look forward to Castle Story's completion whenever it happens, and I hope the devs aren't discouraged by the negative reviews that solely cite the game's slow dev schedule.tl;dr Manage your expectations before buying this or any game. Like a good early access game, mechanics are solid, gameplay is fun if you like RTS-type games that are more in the micro management end of the spectrum, content was lacking but is now solid and constantly improving.

								Just to start, i liked the game it was fun to play, build things, explode barrels inside towers to see them fall, and the survial was fun. content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								Another early access release that will probably never get finished.  All developers claim they are "offering" early access as a means to get the community involved in creative aspects of the game. Or for bug testing reasons. The fact of the matter is they are more than likely in a financial bind and have no other means of finishing the game. Thus, they decide to market their unfinished piece of crap under false pretenses. And once they realise that they have milked their target audience already by selling them an unfinished game. Finishing said game would be pointless in terms of financial gain. We see it time and time again. Its probably time we stop buying into ideas. Ideas dont provide hours upon hours of entertainment.

number of helpful: 10 of 13 people (77%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								I didn't expect this game to be complete because it's Early Access. I didn't, however, expect anything which was being sold to be this incomplete.It's very buggy and there is no purpose to it what so ever. It's not like Minecraft or Terraria because you can't discover or craft. You can collect wood, stone, blue stuff and orange stuff. content:
Posted: March 15
Early Access Review
								I DO like this game. But there are some issues. The biggest, glaring issue, is that castles are simply are NOT the meta in this game. The second is that, despite being a micromanagement simulator, micro in combat does not fly well, although it's absolutely necessary. The first thing I'd like to advise is, save often, and if you lose ANYONE in the hoard mode, you need to reload the save.Now, about the castles part. They simply ARE NOT the most effective defense. You are building castles against creatures that have the ability to punch through walls, and eat several arrows, essentially anti-castle creatures. You don't even have all the historical options to build the castle with anyway. You will simply lack the ability to create arrow slits, machicolations (although I suppose you can make one with the beams and beam slot block, I don't think the archers can use them), and proper gate houses with murder holes. Even if all these things were possible, the micro required to manage these things just isn't there. I've tried several occasions to build a proper keep, three bricks thick. I got to four or five bricks tall before they started completely overwhelming the defense, drilling a hole into the wall, and using that hole as cover. At a certain point, the repair and reset time eats up all your gathering time, meaning the castle will never be completed before you've lost. Now, it seems that, if you leave the castle without a door, you can minimize the damage to the castle, but then your Bricktrons are vulnerable, and at the mercy of you managing their own stupidity.If you want to get to high rounds, it seems the proper way to go about things is to create mazes, full of hurdles that will slow the Corruptrons down. You want to give the Corruptrons a seemingly easy path to your crystal, so that they aren't compelled to break any walls. It takes them extra time to climb up and jump down from blocks. Then, you want to line up your archers so that they face down a long corridor of hurdles, and have your knights hiding around a corner at the end. But getting to high rounds isn't necessarily what I bought the game for, it was more or less for building castles while doing it. Which isn't the most efficient way to accomplish getting higher rounds. That's a problem, in my opinion.Now, about it being a micromanagement simulator. Many people have had problems with the Bricktron building AI, but I've overcome it simply by realizing the sort of order they do things. You cannot create an entire castle in blueprints, and simply let them go about it. It's all about LAYERS. In order to make sure they build things in proper order, you must only place the bricks that immediately come next. So I'm okay with the building AI, more or less.But then comes the combat AI...it's frustrating. Perhaps the tools exist that are a better option than trying to click on a weak Knight and spam-clicking so that they will retreat, or clicking on a tiny point in the command bar (which doen't show which unit is injured), but I haven't found it. There are commands to make the Knights stand still, but they WON'T. Almost every time you try to force them back to the crystal for healing, they immediately want to run back and die (that is, if you tried to build a keep around your crystal like me. If there's enough distance that the AI will not detect the enemy, i.e. the end of a maze build, they won't be as stupid). When in a cluster, it's hard to select the Knight you need to fall back, and it's really annoying that sometimes they won't give you time to select other wounded Knights to fall back before they suicidally try to jump back into the fray and get themselves killed, not to meantion blocking other troops that need to fall back. As for Archers, they have trouble aiming downward.If I were to make suggestions, I would like to ask Sauropod studios to take a look at other RTS games, as well as do more research on actual castles, and make improvements based upon that. A good way to improve the AI is to give the option for a proper stance system, that doesn't reset every time you are trying to move them. Also, clicking in empty space should deselect all things, rather than having to click on the task to unselect. Remove the number keys from the task list, they aren't used and are better suited for creating groups.It is possible to soldier through these faults, but many quality-of-life changes are needed.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								Development is so incredibly slow. I've been watching it since the second day of the kickstarter. Frankly, I'm surprised it hasn't been abandoned yet. There is still some hope, but the game as it is right now is not worth paying for.Pros:- Easy to work with building system- Cute graphics- OK combatCons:- Unintuitive interface, especially the build screen- Poor optimization for pathfinding for anything more than 10 feet away- Tedious management: Catapults don't reload automatically, once a resource area is exhausted they just stop moving- Slow to build, especially when you have to wait for pathfinding- Very shallow combat: archers, footmen, and a catapult. no upgradesI like to compare this game to Stonehearth. The scope of the games is very different, but the core functionality is much the same. Stonehearth accomplishes building much better than Castle Story, by providing scaffolding to help build tall structures. With Castle Story you have to micro-manage pathways, so more complicated builds are incredibly tedious.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								The idea is good, but it becomes vitually implayable after about an hour due to excessive lag. This could be forgiven if the archer AI at least was capable of selecting targets they could actually fire at, as opposed to trying to shoot through walls, friendlies, etc. And even if those issues are not at play, they will stand idle when the nearest enemy is standing below them at the wall, where, remarkably enough, actually dont attempt to shoot through the wall. Nor will they attempt to shoot at an enemy a little further away. They will simply stand and wait for their inevitable demise. Alas their fire cant even be micromanaged due to lag.So at this point you figure, well what the hell, lets toss in the infantry to kill em. After 4-5 lag-killed attempts to drag a selection box around them, you resort to clicking the select all button. Send them in, by clicking at the enemy. The result natually being that most of them end up atop the wall, rather than go outside and kill the enemy. So, the next time round you click outside the wall and pray to god that their AI routine kicks in before they are slaughtered. They usually stare off a good 5 seconds in the distance before this happens, and a lot can go wrong in this time. And did I mention lag?It's a shame, I really liked the concept, but there is just no way to make this game work - these sort of issues should have been filtered out a long long time ago in a 3 year development process as they really dont take long to fix. I dont think this game will end up as advertised.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								There are a lot of reviews that are negative but the vast majority of these address the game in its former state. This review is for the 0.6 Update. Remembering that this game is still in an Early Release state you should expect bugs, glitches, incomplete functions, and less features than a full game. All disclaimers aside I played the game for about an hour tonight and for the first time in several years I finally feel like the game has progressed somewhere. This most recent patch added new gameplay modes and fixed the most gamebreaking bugs that have been around forever (the AI and AI pathing algorithms causing Bricktrons to become stuck doing nothing and unwilling to take any further commands). During the hour of play tonight I ran across no bugs and the longest it took any Bricktron to understand my commands and obey was about 2-3 seconds. Compared to the hours in the past where they would just stand around this is a HUGE improvement. Further, none of them decided to suicide themselves off the side of the island.In it's current state I see many further updates will be needed to complete the game, yes, however it's finally at a point where I can start playing it and enjoy the game. I'm headed to bed now but I'm excited about waking up early to continue my save where I left off tonight. That's a first for me on this game.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								Holy cow this game has burned me so hard over the years. My first and last Kickstarted project, because of this steaming pile right here.It has a lot of potential, I'll give it that. It enchanted me on first glance. It kept me hopeful as the devs failed over and over to make meaningful updates, either written or coded. Not anymore.Boring, buggy, slow, aimless, shallow. That's what we've gotten from 2 years of development. Nary a vision in sight for its future, either. It's sad.Potential is all the game has, and while I'd love to be proven wrong, I'd bet my Library on it never living up to it. Even half to it. The devs just don't have the passion, vision, or experience needed.So yeah, pass. Please, for your own sake, pass. Ignore the cool screenshots and videos.EDIT: Though all of my initial points still stand for the game and studio as it is in the present, this post:http://www.reddit.com/r/CastleStory/comments/2445q8/when_was_the_last_time_we_actually_had_an_update/ch5hwguhas been brought to my attention. If they can deliver on the things listed here, then by all means, it will get my glowing recommendation. Until then, pass.

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								In the current (beta) state I'm not recommending this game at all to anyone but the hardcore players who don't mind weird (annoying, unintuitive, often useless) controls or lack of content (the latter is becoming less of an issue lately).I'd like to point out that I do know what the term "Early access" means. I do understand that bugs can happen, and I'd easily recommend the game should it be just buggy. But the controls I'm complaining of have been just as annoying as they are now for a year (since the prototype) so it's really hard to consider that as a "bug".The devs are working on bringing more and more content to the game and fixing bugs, but the work is amazingly slow (this  beta was at first promised for fall 2012, was then postponed; the prototype came out more or less a year ago by now and apart from new game modes and multiplayer it wasn't much different back then) and some things just never change.The UI and controls have been more or less revamped since the original prototype but are still just as annoying and unusable as they were in that prototype - or even worse.The most basic yet most important action (building blocks) is hard to reach in a weird menu that currently (as far as i know) you can only open by first selecting the builder group then holding the right mouse button and moving the mouse (???) to make the radial menu pop up; while taking a screenshot can be reached by just one click on a dedicated button on top of the screen.Camera movements are less annoying now (you don't have to hold a separate button just to make the camera move/zoom by the mouse) but are still weird compared to any other games I've played.I haven't tried multiplayer so far as sadly my buddies were smart enough not to buy the game yet.The sounds got better since the prototype and the graphics look really good and just as promising as it did 2 years ago on the Kickstarter page. But thanks to all the issues i've listed above currently it's just a wasted opportunity for a good game.

number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								Two years this has been released on early access and it has yet to actullay get finished, reasonably playable or functional. It's a game with a great idea behind it. I love the thought of building a castle and defending it. The issues I have are how this has been executed and the lack of care by the dev team. I've watched this played and I've played it. It doesn't take more than an hour or two to realize that it has some big flaws that need fixing. Once of the biggest issues I've found is that archers, whom you want on towers to get the best shot angle, will randomly decide to run off your tower, killing themselves instantly. This is very frustrating as even the infrantry units will run up a ram to the top of a wall and dive off to their deaths. There are lots of other issues like the controls menu not being properly completed, it still shows the control defined names in the code. The graphics options are bad, even for a Unity game, there can be so many more choices on how to change the graphics.Ideas on how to do basically anything is non-existant. There is a tutorial yes, extremely basic, but it works. It doesn't tell you how to do other tasks like removing blocks, removing tasks or the like.Overall, this is a great idea, just very very very poorly executed. You might get an hour or two of fun out of it. If you are willing to stick with it, deal with the stupid issues that should be fixed, and make it work, then you can get a few more hours out of it.BTW, Multiplayer is non-existant, so that's a big lie there.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								I'm torn on this one. The idea is neat. It is not what I was expecting- I was thinking the units were more automatic a la Dwarf Fortress and randomly built a castle based on certain constraints and orders you set. No, instead, you literally choose to place a blueprint for each and every block of the castle. This is great too, but the issues arise when fighting the rough UI for terrain management and the like. The game has its own style and charm. However, at this point it has very, very awkward controls. Once you begin to get the hang of the system, it gets better, but there is still a lot of fighting against the UI when trying to align zones or work easily by switching bricks (everything runs through a right click/drag menu that has a slowness to it.)Also, and this isn't new for games of this nature with AI beings, you will find your Bricktrons (workers) more often than not standing around doing nothing because they can't find a path, can't find resources that are next to them, or for no apparent reason whatsoever... I just had to quit my first game because a small archer tower I was making was simply deemed impossible to build by my workers- no matter how I tried to rectify issues, they stood there doing nothing, either complaining about resoruces that were i a nearby stockpile, or unable to path to some point, even though there were stairs or other means of traversal. Not a unique problem for games of this sort, but it is in need of work as of June 2016.Now, all that said, I think the game is headed for a successful conclusion, it simply needs more TLC from the devs, who seem to be on the ball. If I could ask for one thing though, it would be a more streamlined UI with ease of use (and speed) in its place. For instance, once in "build" mode, you could quickly choose block types via the scroll wheel. I currently give it a yes, but with the knowledge it is not as smooth an experience as other games of its sort at this point. Looking forward to future iterations.

								After playing a few games through I was in. I love the idea of this game and I look forward to the devs fixing the game breaking bugs. The pathfinding leaves much to be desired. Your knock-off minon characters, while adorable, aren't the brightest little guys. The building UI is difficult to use and the game seems unbalanced. It takes ages to build anything defendable and I frequently found myself just staring at my screen waiting for my structure to be finished.I anxiously await the bugs to be squished and I will definitely be giving this game another shot after an update... hopefully soon.I say I recommend this game but you may want to add it to your follow list and check it out again after it's gone through an update or two.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								This, is castle story.A game where you can build castles.You can play multiplayer with friends, or singleplayer by yourself.The game originally was broken as heck, but it was heavily patched up and fixed.For an early access game it is very good quality from what it originally was.The gameplay itself is fun, but more fun in multiplayer.You have three units, and a catapult you can build.In order to build with stone you have to designate a quarryAnd in order to build with wood you have to chop trees.Pretty easy, right?NOT SO! In both multiplayer and survival you have to defend your workers against rival players and corrupted stone monsters!Unless you don't like fighting, which you can play sandbox mode, and build in peace.Thanks for reading.TL;DRSandbox elements, with some Strategy.

								the game is great... i get this is an early early game but the game is unplayable most of the time and just anoying, not fun. they need to fix these problems.the grafics reminds me of the first age of empires made, that needs to be updated. the grass is bright green lol.the combat system is so dumb. its clunky and buggy. one of your knights sees an enermy 5 spaces away, so they run that 5 spaces to attack, mind you the enermy unit has moved from that location but your knight still runs there and attacks nothing, then has to run to the new postion and attacks nothing again if the enermy has moved again.if you build a big tower with archers on it and an enermy destroys 3 or 4 blocks on one corner of the tower, some of the blocks on top drop down and you carnt re-build the blocks that are higher then 2 high. idk it seems abit dumb.the bugs with workers are great. your worker or most of your workers get locked into a job but wont do the job there stuck in so they do nothing. so you have to get them killed to build another worker.if the game is 20 bucks and they some how finish this game, wtf is the price going to be? 50 bucks (i just threw up).

content:
Posted: June 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								Another wave of black clay men are quickly advancing towards the southern walls of my Castle. On the wall stands a group of my yellow clay men workers, having just finished a big renovation project after the wall was almost destroyed in a previous assault. They stand no chance of holding the wall so I scroll over to my group of warriors, currently mopping up the few remaining hostiles who just tried to destroy my western walls. I order most of my warriors and archer to rush to southern walls, If I am lucky they will make it there before the attackers and I will be able to hold my castle, if not they will swam into my courtyard, kill my workers and surround my warriors. I am confident that my warriors will be able to hold my newly completed and fortified walls so instead I have a look at my recently attacked western side. There is small gap in the wall caused by the now dead attackers that I need to get repaired before any additional hostiles decide to follow up on their friends previous assault so I have my workers evacuate the soon to be attacked southern walls and send them to fix the bretch. Neither the workers or the warriors arrive. The warriors and the workers run into each others, stopping for what looks like a long and pleasant chat as they try to path around one another failing horribly as the attacker make a huge hole in my new wall. All of my yellow clay men gets surrounded slaughtered.SUMMARY:Castle Story is a game with what sounds like a great concept but has horrible execution. The two biggest issues are the pathing and UI. The pathing causes your claymen to frequently bump into each others, stopping them in their tracks as they try to find a way around their new found friend despite it being plenty of space on both sides of them. The UI requires you to navigate multiple radial menus just to build a stockpile, it is very clunky and unnecessarily complicated. I would stay away from Castle Story, it has been almost 3 years since the initial early access release and not much has happened since then.

								-original review- (2014)This game looked awesome and I was excited for it. When I got the alpha for this game, I thought I saw something that could be great. And for a while I was ok with the small gitchs, and annoying little bugs in the game.YOU SHOULD STAY AWAY FROM THIS GAME. The devs will treat you like crap, and blame the community for asking too many questions, the game has been stagnant for over a year. The forums have started seeing posts deleted, and users are getting banned for giving out useful information, and asking real questions respectfully.-2015 review update- Unfortunately, this game seems to be spinning out of control. The devs have banned anyone asking clear, concise questions regarding the progress. The game was actually more playable two years ago than it is now. They spent a great deal of time refactoring the game, telling us that once this was done, we would start seeing content updates, and real progress. Then, when they claimed the refactoring was done... nothing.. Eventually they abandoned the 'roadmap' and progress lists. They do have a 'bleeding edge' which was being updated fairly frequently for a time, but that too has stopped. Now we have an unplayable game. Instead of fixing the game they had with correct AI, useable UI, Multiplayer, and map editing, they began adding a slew of new 'features', almost none of which actually work.The game was a great concept. It's simplicity was one of its greatest draws. Now it is an incoherent mess.-2016 review update-Castle Story is Becoming the game that it claimed to be at the start.The game has slowly become playable over the course of 2016 however with this development pace the features the devs promised will probably come out in 5 or 6 years I recommend waiting to see if it ever gets a full release before buying the game. This game may yet pull off the 180 and become a game worth buying. However this glimmer of hope may be fools gold because over the time this game has been "In dev" they've been to PAX east, they've ordered in Castle Story T-shirts and Castle Story plushies, they've got new gaming rigs, they've painted the walls of their office with a cool Castle Story mural, they've been out in the woods making noises, they've played Magicite, and just now is the game finally starting to become the game they claimed they had created. This is not the work of a professional dev team this looks a lot like a group of people way over there head and just rolling with it. Lets hope I'm wrong and that they can deliver what they promised while clinging on to the little shard of credibility they have left.TL;DRThe devs have deleted threads or posts with any negative criticism and the development pace is still ridiculous, their shady behaviours (vote manipulation, shills, bans, etc.) howerver seem to have stopped. Come back in 5 years and then buy it on sale if anything has changed.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								Let me start by briefly describing what castle story is. The game is a voxel based, real-time strategy tower defense hybrid with a world editor and a building system that allows for a lot of creativity with a good physics engine. It brings back memories of my childhood playing with Legos (without the mess), allows for builds similar to Minecraft (using blueprints, gathered resources and workers instead of having to do everything through first person) and includes tower defense style elements in a world of floating islands in the sky. The most popular game mode is called Invasion and it tests your defenses against waves of an ever-increasing amount of enemies that can knock your archers off walls, break down your defenses and even throw enemies into your base! To defend yourself you have beefy knights, archers and catapults along with various floor traps such as bear traps and explosive barrels. You can alter the world to change the direction which the enemies take or create bottlenecks where you can do a lot of damage to them. You can team up with friends to help deal with more difficult maps in coop mode. There is also a game mode called conquest where you fight the corruptrons (AI) or other players (multiplayer) for control over different areas of the map with the objective of taking over the entire map. This game type makes defenses less static and brings offensive elements to the game and you can team up with your buddies to take on the AI where you each have your own bases and units. You will inevitably build defenses and leapfrog forward, capturing more and more terrain.Based on the recent improvements to the game, it seems the development team has grown, as can be seen in the increase to both the game quality and responsiveness in community feedback. The game’s most recent patch, 0.7, brought with it a lot of great changes and many people who played it before this patch and didn’t like it or had performance issues may want to try it again. There is now a world editor which is both powerful and quick and easy to use. Multiplayer has been implemented as well. Moreover, the performance of this game has improved greatly and your builders and warriors respond much better and quicker. While I did enjoy the game before the most recent patch, the game has improved leaps and bounds and it seems the developers have doubled down in their efforts to flesh it out and polish it. There is an active and growing community of mapmakers and active players as well, both new and old. However, that said there are a few cons to the game in its current form: the game still has its fair share of bugs, especially prevalent in the recently introduced multiplayer. Additionally, multiplayer can be tricky to set up, though they are working on implementing a better system/ dedicated server. The game isn’t for everyone as it demands patience and planning but can be extremely rewarding once you understand the basics. While the game might initially seem simple, there is a surprising depth to it once you get to know the mechanics and since the game is still in development, your ideas and concepts might be implemented into future patches. Looking back at how much I have played and enjoyed this game, I think it’s worth the full price, though I did buy it when it was on sale. If you are dedicated to the concept or want to support an indie developer that has doubled down its efforts, I suggest you pick it up or at least put it on your wish list and wait for it to be on sale.The verdict:If you: enjoy voxel based games that allow you to build whatever and however you want with a world editor and physics-based construction, like tower defense games that test your patience and strategic thinking in which you can immerse yourself and relax, like real-time strategy, resource management and building bases brick by brick, then this game is for you.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								First of all, the game's really early release, so I didn't expect much. But I got even less that that, in my opinion. While there is a ton of potential, and I'm really looking forward to what the game COULD be, right now it's sorely lacking in quite a few areas.The first, and by far the biggest and worst, area is the controls. Less than half of the controls actually feel streamlined and as if they should work. All the rest are clunky, hard to remember, and completely out of left field. I mean, hold space and drag your middle mous click to move your camera? What? And the controls can't be changed individually according to task. You can just change what keystrokes/clicks the game recognizes. So, for example, you can't change the "turn blueprint" key, oh no. You have to change right click entirely, which messes with about 6 other keybinds at the same time. So, yeah, the ENTIRE control scheme needs reworked to something a human would use, not an alien.Next are your citizens, or "bricktons". Now, I know, there are probably a few bugs still, but it's really sad how bad it is right now. It takes around 5 seconds for them to realize you gave them an order, their pathing is atrocious because as soon as they find a path that works, they don't change it again, even if you make a shorter one, unless you force them to. They block each others' movement, forcing you to babysit them just in case they trap each other in somewhere doing the whole "East Going Zax, West Going Zax" routine. And sometimes they just refuse to listen at all when you tell them to do things, instead opting to stand about 3 times away from the job and staring. So they need to be able to occupy the same space, and the AI needs reworked big time.Then there's the digging. I hate the way the quarry works, because you can't make a custom size, only a custom depth, which leaves the land looking terrible with deep♥♥♥♥♥holes pock-marking your areas instead of one nice, large hole that encompasses all you needed to mine. TUNNELING IS THE WORST AND MOST TEDIOUS THING I HAVE EVER DONE IN A GAME, I DON'T EVEN KNOW HOW IT GOT SO BAD. You literally have to tunnel horizontally ONE BLOCK at a time, going back to reassign the job every time they finish it, having to reassign the workers, too, because you can't have multiple tunnel jobs on one order. So, basically, make the whole digging scene more customizable, and have it not be the single most tedious task you will ever do. Also, randomized maps wouldn't hurt. I don't like playing with the same map over and over.And as for the building? Other than the keybind madness that the alien that designed this game came up with, it's good. I enjoy the customizability and the different options and stuff that are in the game. That being said, though, it could do with some fine tuning, such as some keybinds to move your blueprint one space at a time, that way the horrific mouse detection isn't so infuriating.Lastly, there's the UI. It's sweet, simple, to the point. A little boring, but good. One thing I would definitely change, though, is make it so you can toggle the task bar to stay open by just clicking the little star. Just one of those picky little things.Now, for the moment of truth. Despite the scores of flaws I see so far, the game has a ton of potential. It just needs some tender loving care from the devs and the community to bring it up from the depths of hell. So do I recommend this game. No. Not at all. At least, not YET. Because I don't want anyone's vision of this game tainted by the current build. But eventually, when it gets worked on some more? By all means, yes. Buy it. I did have some fun with it, after all.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								EDIT: After A bit of further testing almost 9 months after I last touched the game, it looks like things have gotten even worse. Granted, some new maps and features have been added, like Iron, but now your brisktrons will randomly path themselves off the map, committing suicide in the name of hauling lumber. I've also encounterd an issue where the game freezes for seceral seconds, and then all of your bricktrons are all stuck falling, unable to move or do anything else, leabing you no ther option than to quit and star over, or reload from a save file. :END EDITI purchased this game on EA about 6 months ago after seeing several videos of gameplay. It looked promising. I was excited for a more realistic base builder so to speak. I didnt expect the game to be too fleshed out yet, since that's what early access is. Having played several hours, and feeling like the game had great potential, I put the game down to come back after the devs had ahd a few months to work on it.Queue last week. I booted up the game, started a new game, and began building the exact same castle on the exact same map I had before. As the first wave of baddies approached, I noticed that they ran around willy-nilly, and just seemed to punch at anything. not particularly impressed, I continued.About 10 minutes later, it became evident that some work had been done to the AI engine since last I played. Except it seems that the work had been to delete half the brains of all the entities in the game. The workers would regularly all attempt to place the same block, take the same narrow path when there were a multitude of options, and regularly block each other in to the point where 5 of them were all stuck in one spot, all trying to get past each other, but to no avail. I even noticed the knights swinging their swords the WRONG WAY when in combat. I real flop if you ask me.All in all, the game looks promising, but it appears that the dev studio is working by the old creedence "One step forward, two steps back"

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								I have waited for this game for so long. I love the idea, and the characters are absolutely adorable. Although, I had no idea it was still in "early access." I haven't played too much of it yet, but I have already encountered the problem of Bricktrons just standing around even though you have assigned them a job. I didn't even try to save yet. Also, when recalling your workers, they shouldn't just decide "oh the danger is gone" on their own, because they are always wrong. They walk right outside while the Corruptrons are still there and let them inside to kill everyone. I shouldn't have to repeatedly recall my workers while the soldiers are fighting outside. I still reccommend that you keep an eye on this game, just don't buy it yet, unless you think the price will sky rocket later. If these bugs are fixed, it will be one of the most fantastic village survival games out there.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								Feelings of disillusioned loomed 6 months ago, but with a recent update proudly touting the return of the pause function and that objects that fall into the abyss are now removed from the world instead of indefinitely floating in space, it became clear this game would never deliver.  Did the people that wrote the seed leave/die, or is Sauropod simply out of their depth in taking on this sizable AI feat?  There's been no appreciable improvement in minion behavior-- which is crucial to this game -- for a year.  Even things that seem like obvious bug squashes loom.  They still kick the logs they just harvested off the edge of the world.  They still go idle randomly.  They still build themselves into a corner.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								8/8/2016I decided to try Castle Story again today. I installed it and it straight up just dosen't load. A small box pops up with options about how to start the game. It's set to standard (only option) graphics.When I hit play... the screen turns purple and music starts playing.Sigh, why do I keep trying this game?DO NOT BUY.---12/28/2014I tried the new update and noticed quite a few improvements. I wouldn't say it's worth buying yet though.Update Pros:- Things feel a little bit more smooth.  The AI didn't seem as bad as when I previously played.- The explainations and ingame notfications are getting better.- Seems to be less lag with some speed improvements overall.Cons:- Islands are still too small.- AI needs work still.  Seems to be 1 out of 5 times you interact with a Brickton they will stop responding entirely. This leads to a bit of an issue considering some of your Bricktons are archers/warriors. I've lost my base a few times due to this bug.- Saving is hit or miss.  Sometimes saved games work perfectly... most times Bricktons go missing or it crashes on load.- Clicking on workers has become challenging. It isn't as nice to right click and drag to select multiple workers now.All statements in previous review still apply.----6/28/2014I've had this game for quite a few months now and I'm still excited about what it could become.With that said...  the game isn't close to being finished and there are quite a few baffling design decisions that have been made.- Why islands? The small terrain causes incredible frustration while trying to do the most basic things. The islands themselves aren't necessarily the problem but it's how the game can't handle them. The AI is incredibly buggy and stops responding or gets confused on the narrow strips of land. Also, the majority of trees harvested end up flying off the map.- Additional ContentWhy continue to add other content (multi-player?!? etc) on top of a not-solid base game?Please don't continue to build ontop of a game that needs some serious overhauls in level design, AI design, general gameplay, and in-game priorities.With all that being said, I hope they turn it around and figure it out. Every once and awhile I'll play it for an hour or so.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								Even though I recommend this game, it's really recommended to a more specific group than just to everyone.Pros:- Developers are quite interactive with the community on their youtube page "sauropodstudio" where you can ask questions as they stream the game every Friday at 3pm US Central time.- Bugs are few in number and if reported correctly are taken care of quickly.- Controls are easy to use for RTS veterans and easy to learn for everyone else.- Pathfinding, for your troops, is well developed for a building RTS.- *Personal Taste* The graphical fedelity is pleasing to the eye.- *Personal Taste* The gameplay is simple so not to have unneeded extras.Cons:- The game requires a reasonably powerful computer setup to play on anything but simple graphics.- The game is run on Unity engine which makes the game choppy when you get into later levels with larger waves of enemies.- *Personal Taste* Some of the more interesting additions have yet to be added to the game.- The AI pathing for the enemies can be exploited to make the game trivial.- *Personal Taste* For the current amount of content, the price is a little too high.- It has no real tutorial so you'll have to watch videos, or look at the wiki for help.- Development is slow due to their small team.Recommendation is to RTS fans, who cross over with Building fans, such as minecraft, with those who enjoy an easier simpler form of Dwarf Fortress. Buy only if you really believe that the developers vision of the outcome of the game matches your own and you you don't mind waiting for it to be worked out by there relatively small team.

number of helpful: 8 of 13 people (62%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								I really want to like this game, but the most important thing standing in my way is the interface.I don't fancy playing in creative, so my view is from the survival aspect. In survival you have to quickly start building a castle and defend it against wave after wave of ever-increasing numbers of attackers. The key word here is quickly.There is no pause, so you cannot stop and plan your castle out and then set your people to work, so you are instantly stressed. This could be fine if the interface otherwise supported speedy planning and building, but it does not.The game seems very much built for consoles (or at least using a controller) because it just about only uses the mouse totally disregarding the keyboard for anything but camera navigation. In a game with so many things to build, getting even the simplest things made is a pain.In order to build anything you have to first click the right mouse button and hold it for about 1 second. Then choose build mode. Then right click and hold for about a second again to get a radial menu where you then select the category of things you want to build and then you can finally select the specific item you want. So even building the simplest little storage box quickly takes 3-4 seconds. If you then want to switch items you want to build, you have to again hold the mouse and go through the waiting once more. In a game where you have 10 minutes before the first wave of attackers and ever less time before the next attacks spending 3-4 seconds per item you want to place into the world will make you frustrated beyond compare.Again, I love the style and the idea, but the interface just kills it.It seems like the designers like a sleek no on-screen menu interface so much they are willing to sacrifice a lot to get it. I urge them to reconsider seeing as any amount of waiting for menus in a no-pause survival game is infuriating and stressfull and is bad game design. Please, dear designers, consider adding a toolbar at the bottom and more use of the keyboard so the all the waiting for menus goes away, or at least add a pause function. A pause function would not remove the irritating wait time, but it would remove the infuriating stressfulness.

Early Access Review
								I'm torn no this, honestly. I love the game, and the gameplay, and basically all its elements. BUT in the two years I've owned it (and eagerly awaited progress mind you), nothing has been achieved or established. A part of me wants to encourage this type-of-game but not this development method, but unfortunately those are mixed due to steam early access. So in short; if its on sale for less than 10$ hop on it, if its more than that ask yourself if you want to encourage this kind of almost transparent money grabs taking good ideas and basically ruining them.

number of helpful: 11 of 19 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								I highly advise against buying this game. The developers don't ever update the game and they never fix the glitches and bugs (which are plentiful). The A.I. is horrible and the characters are almost always running into each other and just randomly standing in the way for like 7 seconds at a time. There is also a serious lack of content. There is just one mode, where you have to hold out against the enemy A.I. and hope that your own broken characters who don't know how to walk don't get run down because they can't climb stairs. I am pretty sure that the people who made this game took the money and ran. Don't buy this game unless you want to regret spending $20.EDIT: December 30, 2016OK, so I have come back and looked at the game 2 years later, and I have a few more comments to make on this game. The dev team has finally added some more game modes, so we know that they haven't completely abandoned ship. The problem with this is that they are fixing the things that didn't necessarily need to be fixed. There is still a serious lack of content in  other areas. In this game, when the players wanted updates they wanted more real content, such as more characters to use, not more gamemodes that give us different ways to play a broken and unenjoyable game. Some people will say, "It's in early access, quit whining, it's supposed to be bad, blah blah blah." The thing is though, that this game has been in early access since 2012, when I bought it. In 4 years, the only thing that they have accomplished is adding multiplayer, so your friends can join in on the unpleasant experience. They also added a new enemy, but that doesn't matter if the game is unplayable. The game doesn't even have more than one graphics setting, which is "standard" (it isn't even that good of a graphics setting). For now my review still stands, and I for sure do not recommend buying this game.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is going to be used as a textbook example of why you should never buy an early access game.  These guys sold a lot of copies of an exercise turned tech demo.  If I were in their boots, I'd be done.  Why make a game when you cut your losses and run... and by losses, I mean a whole lot of cash up front with absolutely zero accountability to finish the game.Yes, early access means it's not done... and that's the problem with early access; It never has to be done to be sold. NEVER!I wish I was back in school where I would make little "game" concepts.  A few exercised examples and you pass.  Never had to worry about making it a full functioning game... that would have taken the entire semester if not longer to finish. ...but if I polished it just enough to put on kickstarter... cha-ching!  A few days or months of work for a pay out equivalent to the entire gaming dev life-cycle.  From a purely financial point of view, the payout from work is done.

Early Access Review
								If you like to watch Grass Grow and Bones Decay, this game is for you.  This group uses all the Playbook excuses you can have for not actually having any New Content in two years. The Dog ate the coders work notes....Please don't fall into their trap. I was a Kickstart supporter 2 years ago before it made it here.  The game idea is neat but there are far more better developed games being churned out elsewhere Monthly.  Stay away from this game until at least the Year 2020.I love the Defensive Responses to pretty simple Questions. You'd think these guys were developing something for the Government.  This game needs to be put in the hands of REAL developers period. Maybe they can make some sissy iOS games for crappy Mobile devices but as far as I see this is a joke. Utter waste of Money and Time. The KS requested only 85k yet they get a huge 700k and this is where we are.  Steam needs to pull this Off the list now!So Now they resolve issues on things they don't want to see or answer with Deleting the Post. I was within the guidelines and 3 times over the last month my post has been deleted. It's clear these guys are tired of bad press but until everyone knows about it you should NOT pay for this crap plain and simple. I can not believe the utter unprofessional attitude these guys have. They have NO business sense at all.7-9-2016  So after leaving this game for Dead 2 years ago I figured after an Update notice on game I would load it up... WOW. ABOUT F'ing time. content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
Early Access Review
								I thought this game was going to be great.. i really did. but there are way too many bugs for me to enjoy it. i know it is in beta so there should be bugs but there are too many game-breaking bugs. i only get to actually play the game about 25% of the time. When i click play, 75% of the time nothing shows up yet it says im playing it. this has happens way too often.Also, it crashes. It crashes a lot. So i need to save my game every five minutes so i dont lose progress when it crashes. But, after about four crashes in one setting, it gets better, but i still save a lot to be safe.Lastly, the A.I is almost completely broken. At first they work well for about four waves besides when half of the bricktrons stand in place when i call them back to the castle when the corrupted are coming. After about wave four, the builders dont build, and when i click on them to move somewhere they stand still. Even the corrupted are buggy. half of the time, they go straight past the castle and stand on the edge of the island and i need to send my warriors after them to get the loud, but good, music to stop. And half the time the warriors just stand in place as thcorrupted raid my castle and kill all of my bricktrons.Ok, that was a lot of hate. I do like this game when it works, but dont think you should buy it for the $20.00 price until its fixed. This game can be good, but needs a lot more work and i think you should wait until its out of beta or at least a bit more fixed.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								I, like many, originally backed this game on Kickstarter. The very nature of kickstarter is like most other investments, where the backers are absorbing all the risk on a promise of some sort of return, be it financial or in this case, a game. Of the various things I've backed on Kickstarter, this is the only one I truly regret.Why?Anything that I say has already been said in other reviews. The progress in development has been incredibly, painfully slow. Games that were pitched/came out after Castle Story have rapidly over taken it in every way. Commonly cited examples are Space Engineers and Prison Architect.Even if you could objectively state that development progress isn't slow, consumer psychology is a powerful thing. Why are goods sold for £0.99 instead of £1.00? We perceive it to be far cheaper, when the reality isn't such. If people believe development progress to be slow, then it's slow unless you definitively prove otherwise.So if I agree with the other reviews, why am I coming out of the woodwork?It's the antagonistic nature with which this studio engages with the player base. There will always be people who are unhappy, it's the very nature of exchanging money for goods/services. However, beneath all the anger and poorly chosen words are legitimate concerns and questions that go unanswered, or worse still, answered with equal levels of vitriol and abrasion. Think of the silent observers, like I used to be, quietly asking the same questions? Some of the exchanges between the community and the developers of this game are legitimately scary. Reading the castle story subreddit was an eye opener.In conclusion, it wasn't a mistake to back this game originally. With the information I had and the strength of their pitch, I was happy to invest and I would do it again. However with all the information available to all of us today, my opinion is that investing would be a mistake. All I can hope is that it would stop them treating the people that invested in their ideas, which by extension means investing in them as people and their future, with such contempt.

One thing I can say is that if I could return this game, I would.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game suffers just like all the other Early release games.  Basically they have a great idea, but they never get past the 90% point.  In professional development this really can't go on.  If beta was suppose to be 1.5 years ago, then it is absurd that we're not at that point.  If any publisher was funding it, it would've been over a long time ago. This is not specific to this game, but I feel I must point it out here, that every month they're doing minor patches instead of large improvements and working toward finishing the game.  I must applaud indie developers on their efforts, but if you're Kickstarted, you have obligations to meet and a game to deliver.As far as playing the game itself, the controls and tutorials were mind-bogglingly poor, and that is the main reason I quit playing.  I still like the idea, but I cannot honestly recommend the game in its current state.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								***EDIT 03-15-2016***"Just forget about this game for the next two or three years", I said... two years ago.  Castle Story is now far more functionnal. Your bricktrons have made tremendous progress in their pathfinding - they now DO manage to go where you ask them. They might still be a bit... slow to accomplish what you order them to do, but eventually, they will succeed - if what you asked them is possible, of course, and you might need a few try & retry to understand their particular logic. But still, as a sandbox game, it manages to realize a good part of what it was supposed to realize - wich is good.  "So why is your review still negative?", might you ask. Well, the answer is quite simple: right now, the game still isn't fun.  First of all, the bricktrons are slow, and building anything takes a HUGE amount of time. The IA isn't exactly helping about that, and it is a shame that the devs still haven't thought about the first button you would think of in this game - a button to fast forward, that is.  Second, there are little options in the matter of building. A few stone bricks, a few woodlogs (very complicated to use, by the way), you should be building very little variations of the same model of towers and walls pretty quickly. After two or three hours, the game is already awfully repetitive.  That's were the "invasion" mode might get fun: testing the resistance of your citadel by repelling infinite waves of ennemies. Well, problem is: too few ennemies variations, too few units, and most of all, the IA is a mess and cannot hope to compete with any RTS' AI. Your archers might actually be more dangerous for you own troops, and the knights never do anything right; and of course, you have no real control about the attitude they should use. So, for now, the strategy is rather plain: build a tall tower, put all your achers on top of it, rince, repeat. And pray that the ennemies don't get at the base of the tower, for your bricktrons are too dumb to lean and shoot downward. And, to make matter worse, repairing any damaged structure is a real pain in the back, as your bricktron can't seem to fix anything beyond their reach, their reach being something around two yards high. Of course, that's precisely the height where the ennemies like to dig (sigh).  So it appears that I still was awfully optimistic when I told people to wait for two or three years: right now, I do believe that Castle Story will finally be a fun and fully working game around the year 2020.*** *** *** ***ORIGINAL REVIEW:This looks like a hit. This smells like a hit. Too bad, for months now it's been nothing but a buggy, twice-in-a-year-updated wreck of a game. Your builders are stupid, they can't do anything right. Nothing of what you see in the trailers is actually doable right now. So, my two cents: just forget about this game for the next two or three years, maybe it' ll become something that you might actually call "a game". Right now it's an expensive prank.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game suffers just like all the other Early release games.  Basically they have a great idea, but they never get past the 90% point.  In professional development this really can't go on.  If beta was suppose to be 1.5 years ago, then it is absurd that we're not at that point.  If any publisher was funding it, it would've been over a long time ago. This is not specific to this game, but I feel I must point it out here, that every month they're doing minor patches instead of large improvements and working toward finishing the game.  I must applaud indie developers on their efforts, but if you're Kickstarted, you have obligations to meet and a game to deliver.As far as playing the game itself, the controls and tutorials were mind-bogglingly poor, and that is the main reason I quit playing.  I still like the idea, but I cannot honestly recommend the game in its current state.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								Having sunk hours upon hours into this game I can safely say, this is an incredible game in its own right.Whilst updates are rather infrequent with new content being added every 2 months or so, the game itself is endless fun. It does take a while to wrap your head around a few of the building mechanics but after doing so it is ridiculously satisfying, allowing you to build gigantic castles and towers from which your units can attack.The multiplayer is also a lot of fun with a rather bizarre take on a strategy game, rather than building a town to support your units development, you are literally building a castle and a few small outposts to defend shards that you must capture to give yourself an edge in PvP.The one downside I would say this game has is that it is a bit slow to start, however this is remedied by the fact you can summon waves when you are ready for them, meaning you can summon the first 20 or so waves within 20 clicks. This is virtually suicide but if you feel like doing this, go for it.I would highly recommend this game.
